revision.comment: +[[Category:18th-century Russian scientists]]; ±[[Category:18th-century scientists]]→[[Category:18th-century German scientists]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Daniel Gottlieb Messerschmidt | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = September 16, 1685 | birth_place = [[Danzig]] | death_date = March 25, 1735 | death_place = [[Saint Petersburg]] | other_names = | known_for = Exploring [[Siberia]] | occupation = Physician | nationality = German }} '''Daniel Gottlieb Messerschmidt''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|Да́ниэль Го́тлиб Ме́ссершмидт}}) (September 16, 1685 – March 25, 1735) was a German physician, [[natural history|naturalist]] and [[geographer]]. He was born in [[Danzig]] and studied medicine in [[Jena]] and [[Halle, Saxony-Anhalt|Halle]], obtained his [[doctorate degree]] in the latter in 1713 and settled as a medical doctor in [[Danzig]]. In 1716, he came into contact with [[Russia]]n emperor [[Peter the Great]]. By decree of November 5, 1718, Peter gave Messerschmidt the task to ”collect rarities and medicinal plants” from [[Siberia]].
Messerschmidt set out in 1720 on his exploration – the first by a [[natural history|naturalist]] in this ''[[terra incognita]]'', which came to last for seven years. He made numerous observations related to [[ethnology]], [[zoology]] and [[botany]] and also excavated the first known [[fossil]] [[mammoth]] remains. Messerschmidt used two simple utensils for collecting data and artefacts, written diary notes and boxes, establishing a tradition for [[natural history|naturalist]] exploration to last for a century.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = te Heesen | first = Anke | title = Boxes in Nature | journal=Studies in History and Philosophy of Science Part A | volume = 31 | issue = 3 | pages = 381–403 | year = 2000 | doi = 10.1016/S0039-3681(00)00017-0}}</ref> In [[Tobolsk]], Messerschmidt met the [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[lieutenant colonel]] [[Philip Johan von Strahlenberg]], who had been taken prisoner at the [[Battle of Poltava]] and [[exile]]d to [[Siberia]].
Strahlenberg accompanied Messerschmidt during several expeditions and later published some of Messerschmidt’s observations.<ref>{{Cite book | last = von Strahlenberg | first = Ph.J. | title = Das Nord- und Östliche Theil von Europa und Asia | year = 1730 | location = Stockholm | url = | isbn = }}</ref> Messerschmidt explored lands all the way to [[Argun River (Asia)|Argun]] east of [[Lake Baikal]].<ref name="Egerton (2008)">{{Cite journal | last = Egerton | first = Frank N. | title = A History of the Ecological Sciences, Part 27: Naturalists Explore Russia and the North Pacific During the 1700s | journal=Bulletin of the Ecological Society of America | volume = 89 | issue = 1 | pages = 39–60 | year = 2008 | doi = 10.1890/0012-9623(2008)89[39:AHOTES]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> The journey, however, exhausted him, and he returned to [[Saint Petersburg]] in February 1728. He never became a member of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Academy of Sciences]]. He died in [[poverty]] in 1735.
[[File:Messer0002.jpg|thumb|''Cypripedium macranthon'', described by Messerschmidt]] Messerschmidt’s notes and collections were, to the degree they were preserved, kept at the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Academy of Sciences]] in [[Saint Petersburg]]. [[Peter Simon Pallas|Pallas]] cited extracts of his journey log in his ''Neue nordischen Beyträge''. Only much later, his full journal and excellent maps were published.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Messerschmidt | first = D.G. | title = Forschungsreise durch Sibirien 1720–1727, vol. 1–5, edited by E. Winter and N.A. Figurovskij | series = Quellen und Studien zur Geschichte Osteuropas | date = 1962–1977 | location = Berlin | url = | issn = 0079-9114}}</ref> In his travel journal, he described 149 minerals, 1290 plants of which 359 occurring in [[Russia]] only, and more than 260 [[vertebrate]]s.<ref name="Egerton (2008)"/>
== Literature == * Han F. Vermeulen: 'Enlightenment and Pietism. D. G. Messerschmidt and the Early Exploration of Siberia'. (=Ch.3). In: Han F. Vermeulen: ''Before Boas. the genesis of ethnography and ethnology in the German Enlightenment''. Lincoln & London, University of Nebraska Press, 2016. {{ISBN|978-0-8032-5542-5}}
== References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Messerschmidt, Daniel Gottlieb}} [[Category:1685 births]] [[Category:1735 deaths]] [[Category:17th-century German people]] [[Category:18th-century German people]] [[Category:18th-century Russian people]] [[Category:18th-century explorers]] [[Category:18th-century German scientists]] [[Category:18th-century geographers]] [[Category:Imperial Russian explorers]] [[Category:Imperial Russian scientists]] [[Category:Imperial Russian botanists]] [[Category:Botanists active in Siberia]] [[Category:Imperial Russian geographers]] [[Category:German explorers]] [[Category:German scientists]] [[Category:German botanists]] [[Category:German geographers]] [[Category:History of Siberia]] [[Category:German emigrants to the Russian Empire]] [[Category:People from Gdańsk]] [[Category:18th-century Russian scientists]]

'''Deer in the Works''' is a short story by [[Kurt Vonnegut]]. It first appeared in ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' in April 1955, and was anthologized in ''[[Welcome to the Monkey House]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Marc|first=Leeds|last2=Reed|first2=Peter|title=Kurt Vonegut: Images and Representations|url=https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&docId=27675552|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|accessdate=18 December 2010}}</ref>
After [[World War II]] Vonnegut worked as a writer at the [[General Electric]] plant in [[Schenectady]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Ilium frequently appears in his writings, and is supposed to be the hometown of his character, [[Kilgore Trout]].
In 1980 the story was made into a short film with a running length of 25 minutes. The film stars [[Dennis Dugan]] in the lead role with supporting roles played by [[Gordon Jump]], [[Bob Basso]], [[Richard Kline]] and [[Bill Walker (actor)|Bill Walker]]. The film was directed by [[Ron Underwood]] and the screenplay adaptation was written by [[Brent Maddock]] and [[S. S. Wilson]]. The film was produced by [[Barr Films]].
==Plot== David Potter, owner of a small town weekly [[newspaper]], decides to get a more secure job. Despite his wife's misgivings, he applies to be a publicity writer at the mammoth [[Ilium (Kurt Vonnegut)|Ilium]] Works. Although shaken at seeing how the company immediately plans out his entire career, he accepts the position. He is then given his first assignment, recording the capture of a [[deer]] that has slipped onto the grounds of the Works. After he and a [[photography|photographer]] finish their jobs the deer will be killed and served at a company dinner.<ref name="Book Rags">{{cite web|title=Welcome to the Monkey House - Deer in the Works Summary & Analysis|url=http://www.bookrags.com/studyguide-welcome-to-the-monkey-house/chapanal018.html#gsc.tab=0|publisher=Book Rags|accessdate=14 May 2017}}</ref>
Getting hopelessly lost, Potter views the utter [[dehumanization]] of the workers. Mistaken for a visiting scientist, he joins a party and has several drinks before finding a skirmish line of employees closing in on the deer. He opens a gate, lets it escape, and then follows it out into the world.<ref name="Grade Saver">{{cite web|title=Kurt Vonnegut's Short Stories Summary and Analysis of "Deer in the Works"|url=http://www.gradesaver.com/kurt-vonnegut-short-stories/study-guide/summary-deer-in-the-works|publisher=Grade Saver|accessdate=14 May 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Deer In The Works}} [[Category:Short stories by Kurt Vonnegut]] [[Category:1955 short stories]] [[Category:Works originally published in Esquire (magazine)]]
{{Short-story-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox rugby biography | name = Alex Angus | image = | birth_name = Alexander William Angus | nickname = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1889|11|11}} | birth_place = [[Sydney]], [[Australia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1947|03|23|1889|11|11|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]] | height = | weight = | ru_position = Forward | ru_nationalteam = {{flagicon|SCO}}[[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] | ru_nationalcaps = 18 | ru_nationalpoints = (9) | ru_ntupdate = | ru_nationalyears = 1909-1920 | ru_clubyears = | ru_clubupdate = | ru_clubcaps = | ru_clubpoints = | ru_proclubs = [[Watsonians RFC]] | occupation = | school = | university = }} '''Alexander "Alex" William Angus''' (11 November 1889 – 23 March 1947) was a Scottish international [[rugby union]] and cricket player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnscrum.com/statsguru/rugby/player/2024.html?class=1;template=results;type=player;view=match|title=Alexander Angus: International profile|accessdate=9 August 2012|publisher=Scrum.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/player/25142.html |title=Alexander Angus |work=www.espncricinfo.com |publisher= |date= |accessdate=7 December 2013}}</ref>
He was capped eighteen for the {{nrut|Scotland}} rugby union team between 1909 and 1920.<ref name=Bath1/> He played club rugby for [[Watsonians RFC|Watsonians]].<ref name=Bath1>Bath, p104</ref>
Richard Bath mentions him as one of the three Scottish players "who've gone the longest without (between) scoring a try for Scotland" along with [[Alan Tait]] and [[Gary Armstrong (rugby)|Gary Armstrong]].<ref name=Bath2>Bath, p64</ref> This is partly because [[World War I]] occurred in the middle of his international career, a period in which all international rugby ceased. He was first capped in 1909, scoring two tries in fourteen matches before the Great War.<ref name=Bath2/> His next four caps came in 1920, and he scored against {{nrut|Ireland}} on 28 February 1920 - just over nine years since his previous try.<ref name=Bath2/> Scotland won that match 19-0.<ref name=Bath2/>
He also played for the [[Scotland national cricket team]].<ref name=Bath1/>
==See also== * [[List of cricket and rugby union players#Scottish|List of Scottish cricket and rugby union players]] * [[Jock Wemyss]] and [[Charlie Usher]], other players capped on both sides of the war.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== * Bath, Richard (ed.) ''The Scotland Rugby Miscellany'' (Vision Sports Publishing Ltd, 2007 {{ISBN|1-905326-24-6}}) * Massie, Allan ''A Portrait of Scottish Rugby'' (Polygon, Edinburgh; {{ISBN|0-904919-84-6}})
{{DEFAULTSORT:Angus, Alex}} [[Category:Scottish rugby union players]] [[Category:Scotland international rugby union players]] [[Category:Scottish cricketers]] [[Category:Watsonians RFC players]] [[Category:1889 births]] [[Category:1947 deaths]] [[Category:Scotland cricketers]]
{{Scotland-rugbyunion-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = File:Marco Rizo.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Marco Rizo Ayala | birth_date = November 30, 1920 | birth_place = [[Santiago de Cuba]], [[Cuba]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1998|9|08|1920|11|30}} | death_place = [[New York City, New York]], U.S. | occupation = Pianist, Composer, Arranger | years_active = 1940–98 }}
'''Marco Rizo Ayala''' (November 30, 1920 – September 8, 1998) was a Cuban-born pianist, [[composer]], and [[arranger]]. He mastered the 19th Century works of composers [[Manuel Saumell]] and [[Ignacio Cervantes]]. He is best known for his role as [[pianist]], arranger and orchestrator for the American television [[sitcom]] ''[[I Love Lucy]]'' which aired from October 15, 1951 to May 6, 1957 on CBS, [[Columbia Broadcasting System]].
Throughout his career which combined the techniques of his classical training with [[Afro-Cuban]] and [[jazz]] rhythms, Rizo recorded nearly 30 albums. He was born in [[Santiago de Cuba]], [[Oriente Province|Oriente]], [[Cuba]].
==Early life==
Rizo’s father, Sebastian, a flutist with the Santiago [[Symphony Orchestra]], served as his son’s first musical instructor. In 1932, Marco moved to [[Havana]] to attend the National [[Conservatory of Music]], where he studied under the tutelage of Spanish composer Pedro San Juan. He remained there for six years, and in 1938 was named the official pianist of the Havana Philharmonic Orquestra, performing under the direction of [[Ernesto Lecuona]]. In 1939, he performed duo piano recitals with [[Ernesto Lecuona]]. Rizo was considered Cuba's most important concert pianist by the age of 16. Rizo became interested in jazz through his work with his father's Rizo-Ayala Jazz Band.<ref name=Obit>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/12/arts/marco-rizo-78-cuban-pianist-and-composer-for-i-love-lucy.html|title=Marco Rizi, 78, Cuban Pianist And Composer for 'I Love Lucy'|author=Watrous, Peter|publisher=New York Times|date=September 12, 1998|accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref>
In 1940, he migrated to the United States, having received a scholarship to the [[Juilliard School]] of Music in New York City. There, he studied under [[Rosina Lhévinne]]. During [[World War II]], Rizo performed and worked with the 2nd Army Military Band.<ref name=Obit/>
==Professional career==
At the end of the war, his childhood friend [[Desi Arnaz]] asked Rizo to join him as the pianist and orchestrator for his band, the [[Desi Arnaz|Desi Arnaz Orchestra]]. He toured the U.S. with the band until 1950. When Arnaz started production of ''[[I Love Lucy]]'', he once again turned to Rizo, hiring him to be the pianist and orchestrator for the show between 1951 and 1957.<ref name=Obit/> Rizo also made several on-camera appearances on the show throughout its run on television. Contrary to popular belief he did not write the I Love Lucy theme by himself which had music by Rizo, Eliot Daniel and Desi Arnaz with lyrics by Harold Adamson.<ref>Entre Amigos Interview, {{cite web|title=http://www.youtube | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6NPEx6dNWQU|accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref> The lyrics were only heard once on the series in the Season three episode 'Lucy's Last Birthday' made in 1953. After the ''[[I Love Lucy]]'' show ended, he remained with [[CBS]] and was the pianist-arranger for the “[[Bob Hope]] Radio Show.”
While in Los Angeles, he attended [[UCLA]] and studied under [[Igor Stravinsky]] and [[Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco]]. Rizo composed motion picture music for Columbia, Paramount and [[MGM Studios]]. He continued his concert career in 1960, playing the music of Lecuona and other Cubans.<ref name=Obit/>
In the early 1970s, Rizo worked as the musical director for the Royal Viking Sea cruise ship. Throughout his career, he arranged for hundreds of top artists: [[Carmen Miranda]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Xavier Cugat]], [[Yma Sumac]], and [[Paquito D’Rivera]], among many others. Some of his most memorable piano and orchestral compositions include “Suite Campesina,” “Ñañigo,” “Danzas Cubanas,” “Jose Marti-Sinfonia Cubana,” “Broadway Concerto,” “Suite of the Americas,” “Suite Española,” and “Visions of New York.”
==Legacy==
In the early 1980s, he founded the non-profit organization “The Marco Rizo Latin American Music Project” (SAMPI), which aimed to spread appreciation for [[Latin music (genre)|Latin music]] and culture to students in universities, colleges, high schools, and public schools.<ref>Entre Amigos Interview, {{cite web|title=http://www.youtube | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HEcplL0FeHc|accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref>
In 1989, Rizo won the Silver Medal of the French Academy of the Arts, Sciences and Letters.
He died of a heart attack in 1998 at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center.<ref name=Obit/> His sister, Vilma Rizo, donated many of his papers, files, and compositions to the Music Division at the [[New York Public Library]] for the Performing Arts located at [[Lincoln Center]] in [[New York City]]. Among the various items in the collection is an unpublished biography that Rizo wrote of his longtime friend Desi Arnaz entitled “The Desi I Knew” (1991).
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

Tamarin | relatives = | school = | university = }} '''Gert Petrus Smal''' (born {{birth date|1961|12|27|df=yes}}, [[Kimberley, Northern Cape|Kimberley]], [[South Africa]]) is a former [[South Africa]]n [[rugby union]] player and assistant coach of the [[South African national rugby union team|South African]] and [[Ireland national rugby union team|Irish]] national rugby union teams. He is currently the Director of Rugby at South African provincial side {{Rut Western Province}} ==Playing career== ===Club career=== Gert Smal was a [[Flanker (rugby union)|flanker]] with [[Leopards (rugby team)|Western Transvaal]] from 1980 to 1983 then played with [[Stellenbosch University]] from 1984 to 1985. Between 1986 and 1990 he was a member of the [[Rugby Rovigo|Rovigo club]] in Italy, as player-assistant coach.{{cite web|url=http://www.leinsterrugby.ie/1131.php |title=Gert Smal Joins Ireland Management Team |publisher=''Leinsterrugby.ie'' |date=2008-06-19 |accessdate=2009-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912023305/http://www.leinsterrugby.ie/1131.php |archivedate=12 September 2008 }} ===Provincial/International career=== Smal had a limited international playing career due to the [[Culture of South Africa#International cultural boycott|international boycott]] of South African sports teams because of the [[apartheid]] regime which ended in 1992. He captained [[South African Gazelles]] (U24 side) in 1984. He turned out for the [[South Africa national rugby union team|Springboks]] against the touring [[New Zealand Cavaliers]] in 1986, against a World Invitation XV in 1989 and a [[Serge Blanco]] World XV team against [[France national rugby union team|France]].{{cite web|url=http://www.irishrugby.ie/283_12549.php|title=Gert Smal Joins Ireland Management Team|publisher=''Irishrugby.ie''|date=2008-06-19|accessdate=2009-12-17}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} He also represented [[Western Province (rugby team)|Western Province]] between 1984 and 1993 and the South African Defence Forces in 1986 and 1987. ====Retirement from playing==== On the Australasian tour with Western Province in 1993, during a match against [[Queensland Reds|Queensland]], Smal received a blow in the mouth causing him to lose vision in the bottom corner of his left eye forcing his retirement from playing.{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/rugby/one-smal-step-for-ireland-1516247.html|title='One Smal step for Ireland'|date=2008-11-01|accessdate=2009-12-17|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}} ==Coaching career== Following the end of his playing career, he was appointed to a number of key coaching positions in South Africa and held coaching positions at the [[Border Bulldogs]] (1998–99), [[Western Province (rugby team)|Western Province]] (2000–02) when they twice won the [[Currie Cup]] and then with the [[Stormers]] in the [[Super 12]] between 2003 and 2005, reaching the semi-finals in 2004. In 2004, Smal was appointed to the South African team management as assistant coach to [[Jake White]], during which time the Springboks won the Tri-Nations championship in 2004 before winning the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]]. When Jake White was replaced by [[Peter de Villiers]] as head coach following the world cup in 2007, Smal offered to develop rugby in the [[Eastern Cape]] but was turned down by the [[South African Rugby Union]] In June 2008, Smal was appointed forward coach to the Irish National team under [[Declan Kidney]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/article-1027727/Ireland-snap-Springbok-coach-Smal.html|title=Ireland snap up Springbok coach Smal|author=Ben Rumsby|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]''|date=2008-06-19|accessdate=2009-12-16}} During Smal's time at Ireland, they won the [[2009 Six Nations Championship|2009 Six Nations]] completing the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]] for the first time [[1948 Five Nations Championship|in 61 years]]. His assistance was key in Ireland's victory over the 2007 World Champions and [[2009 Tri Nations Series|Tri Nations 2009]] champions South Africa during the [[2009 Autumn Internationals]] where he taught the Irish [[Forwards (rugby union)|pack]] some [[Afrikaans]] so that they could read the opposition's [[Line-out (rugby union)|line out]] [[Line-out code|calls]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sarpa.net/view_article.php?id=304|title=Irish read Afrikaans calls at Croke Park|publisher=''The South African Rugby Players Association''|accessdate=2009-12-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823235844/http://www.sarpa.net/view_article.php?id=304|archivedate=23 August 2010|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.planetrugby.com/story/0,25883,3551_5734146,00.html|publisher=''Planet Rugby''|title=Big problem was Smal - Matfield|date=2009-11-30|accessdate=2009-12-16}} In June 2011, he signed a contract extension with the IRFU. Smal was forced to miss the remainder of the [[2012 Six Nations Championship]] after an eye condition struck him. His temporary replacement was [[Munster Rugby|Munster]] forwards coach [[Anthony Foley]].{{cite web|url=http://www.irishrugby.ie/news/25708.php|title=Gert Smal Update|date=24 February 2012|work=irishrugby.ie|accessdate=24 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120908114156/http://www.irishrugby.ie/news/25708.php|archivedate=8 September 2012|df=dmy-all}} Smal was replaced as Ireland forwards coach in 2013 by John Plumtree. ===Western Province=== In 2014, Smal returned to South Africa when he was appointed the Director of Rugby at {{Rut Western Province}} on a three-year contract.{{cite press release | url=http://thestormers.com/smal-appointed-as-western-province-director-of-rugby/ | title=Smal appointed as Western Province Director of Rugby | publisher=Stormers | date=31 March 2014 | accessdate=31 March 2014}} ==Achievements== * '''[[Currie Cup]] 1984, 85 & 86''' with [[Western Province (rugby team)|Western Province]] as player. * '''[[Super 10 (Southern Hemisphere competition)|Super 10]] Championship''' with [[Rugby Rovigo]] as player: 1988 and 1990. * '''[[Currie Cup]] 2000 & 2001''' with [[Western Province (rugby team)|Western Province]] as head coach. * '''[[2004 Tri Nations Series|Tri Nations 2004]]''', with [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]] as assistant coach. * '''[[2007 Rugby World Cup]]''' with [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]] as assistant coach. * '''[[2009 Six Nations Championship|2009 Six Nations]]''' with [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] as forward coach. ==Personal life== He is married to Patti and they have two children, a son Dean and daughter Tamarin. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090329184921/http://www.irishrugby.ie/402_12785.php IRFU Profile] *[http://www.scrum.com/southafrica/rugby/player/10025.html Scrum.com profile] {{DEFAULTSORT:Smal, Gert}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Ireland national rugby union team coaches]] [[Category:South African rugby union players]] [[Category:South African rugby union coaches]] [[Category:White South African people]] [[Category:South Africa international rugby union players]]

{{more footnotes|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name= 411th Bombardment Group <center>[[File:Third Air Force Emblem - World War II.png|60px]]</center> | image=Douglas TA-20G-45-DO 43-21657 (4620868488).jpg | image_size = 290 |caption=A-20G of the 650th Bombardment Squadron<ref>Aircraft is Douglas TA-20G-45-DO serial 43-21657. Note squadron emblem on the nose.</ref> |dates= 1943–1944 |country={{USA}} |branch= [[United States Army Air Forces]] |type= |role=Light Bombardment Replacement Training Unit |size= |command_structure=[[Third Air Force]] |current_commander= |garrison= |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles= |notable_commanders= |anniversaries= }}
The '''411th Bombardment Group''' is an inactive [[United States Army Air Forces]] unit. Its last assignment was with [[III Bomber Command]] at [[Florence Army Air Field]], South Carolina, where it was inactivated on 1 May 1944. In July 1985, the group was reconstituted as the '''411th Tactical Missile Wing''', but has never been active under that name.
==History== The '''411th Bombardment Group''' was activated at [[Will Rogers Field]], Oklahoma on 1 August 1944. Its original squadrons were the 648th, 649th, 650th and 651st Bombardment Squadrons.<ref name=Maurer648BS>Maurer, ''Combat Squadrons'', pp. 694-695</ref><ref name=Maurer649BS>Maurer, ''Combat Squadrons'', p. 695</ref><ref name=Maurer651BS>Maurer, ''Combat Squadrons'', pp. 695-696</ref> Two weeks later it moved to [[Florence Army Air Field]], South Carolina, where it absorbed the personnel of the [[65th Reconnaissance Group]], which had been training observation crews on [[North American B-25 Mitchell]] aircraft there.<ref name=Maurer411BG>Maurer, ''Combat Units'', p. 296</ref><ref>Maurer, ''Combat Units'', pp. 131-132</ref>
The group was a [[World War II]] Replacement Training Unit, using [[Douglas A-20 Havoc]] light bombers. Replacement Training Units were oversized units that trained individual [[aircrew]]s.<ref>Craven & Cate, Vol. VI, introduction, p. xxxvi</ref> After graduating, the airmen were assigned to overseas combat units.<ref name=Maurer411BG/>
However, standard military units, based on relatively inflexible [[table of organization|tables of organization]] were proving poorly adapted to the training mission. Accordingly, the [[Army Air Forces]] adopted a more functional system in which each base was organized into a separate numbered unit.<ref>Goss, p. 75</ref> The group was disbanded on 1 May 1944 and its mission, personnel and equipment were transferred to the 334th Army Air Forces Base Unit (Replacement Training Unit, Light Bombardment).<ref name=Maurer411BG/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/172/006.xml |title=Abstract, History Florence Army Air Field, Mar-May 1944|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=August 28, 2015}}</ref>
On 31 July 1985 the group was reconstituted and redesignated the '''411th Tactical Missile Wing''', but was not activated.<ref name=DAFMPM648q>Department of the Air Force/MPM Letter 648q, 31 July 1985, Subject: Reconstitution, Redesignation, and Consolidation of Selected Air Force Organizations</ref>
==Lineage== * Constituted as '''411th Bombardment Group''' (Light) on 14 July 1943 : Activated on 1 August 1943 : Disbanded on 1 May 1944<ref name=Maurer411BG/> * Reconstituted on 31 July 1985 and redesignated '''411th Tactical Missile Wing'''<ref name=DAFMPM648q/>
===Assignments=== * [[III Bomber Command]], 1 August 1943 * [[I Tactical Air Division]], August 1943 – 1 May 1944
===Components=== * 648th Bombardment Squadron: 1 August 1943 – 1 May 1944<ref name=Maurer648BS/> * 649th Bombardment Squadron: 1 August 1943 – 1 May 1944<ref name=Maurer649BS/> * 650th Bombardment Squadron: 1 August 1943 – 1 May 1944<ref name=Maurer649BS/> * 651st Bombardment Squadron: 1 August 1943 – 1 May 1944<ref name=Maurer651BS/>
===Stations=== * Will Rogers Field, Oklahoma, 1 August 1943 * Florence Army Air Field, South Carolina, 15 August 1943 – 1 May 1944<ref name=Maurer411BG/>
===Aircraft=== * Douglas A-20 Havoc, 1943-1944<ref name=Maurer411BG/> * North American B-25 Mitchell, 1943-1944<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/091/696.xml |title=Abstract, History 411 Bombardment Group|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=August 28, 2015}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|United States Air Force|Military of the United States}} * [[List of A-20 Havoc operators]]
==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|2}}
===Bibliography=== {{Air Force Historical Research Agency}} * {{cite book|editor1=Craven, Wesley F |editor2=Cate, James L |title=The Army Air Forces in World War II|volume=Vol. VI, Men & Planes|year=1955|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago, Illinois|oclc=704158| lccn=48003657}} :: {{cite book|last=Goss|first=William A.|editor=Craven, Wesley F |editor2=Cate, James L|title=The Army Air Forces in World War II|url= |volume=Vol. VI, Men & Planes|year=1955|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago, Illinois|oclc=704158| lccn=48003657|page=|chapter=The Organization and its Responsibilities, Chapter 2 The AAF}} * {{cite book|editor=Maurer, Maurer|title=Air Force Combat Units of World War II|origyear= 1961|url= http://media.defense.gov/2010/Sep/21/2001330256/-1/-1/0/AFD-100921-044.pdf |edition=reprint|year=1983|publisher=Office of Air Force History|location=Washington, DC|isbn=0-912799-02-1|lccn=61060979|pages=}} * {{cite book|editor=Maurer, Maurer|title=Combat Squadrons of the Air Force, World War II|origyear=1969|url= http://media.defense.gov/2010/Dec/02/2001329899/-1/-1/0/AFD-101202-002.pdf|edition= reprint|year=1982|publisher=Office of Air Force History|location=Washington, DC|isbn=0-405-12194-6|oclc=72556|lccn=70605402|pages= }}
==External link== {{commonscatinline|411th Bombardment Group (United States Army Air Forces)}}

{{Distinguish|Zaitokukai}} {{Infobox militant organization |name=Zaitokukai |logo=War flag of the Imperial Japanese Army.svg |caption= |dates=2007Makoto Sakurai, ''Daikenkanjidai'' (大嫌韓時代), Seirindo, 2014, p. 162. –present |leader= Yasuhiro Yagi |motives = |area = [[Japan]] |ideology = [[Fascism|Ultranationalism]]
[[Japanese nationalism]]
[[Religious nationalism]]
[[Ethnic nationalism]]
[[Anti-immigration]]
[[Anti-communism]]
[[Anti-Korean sentiment]]
[[Anti-Chinese sentiment in Japan|Anti-Chinese sentiment]]
[[Anti-Americanism]]
[[Irredentism#Japan|Irredentism]]
[[Reactionary]]
[[Historical negationism]] |crimes = [[Hate speech]], [[Hate crimes]], [[Right-wing terrorism|Far-right terrorism]], [[Gay bashing|Homophobic attacks]] |attacks = |status = Designated as a fascist and extremist organization by the Japanese government and the Western world }} [[File:Zaitokukai rally at Shinjuku on 24 January 2010.JPG|right|thumb|360px|Zaitokukai demonstrating in support of withholding the [[right of non-citizens to vote]] in [[Shinjuku, Tokyo|Shinjuku]] on January 24, 2010]] '''Zaitokukai''', full name {{nihongo||在日特権を許さない市民の会|'''Zainichi Tokken o Yurusanai Shimin no Kai'''|meaning ''Association of Citizens against the Special Privileges of the [[Koreans in Japan|Zainichi]]''}}, is an [[ultra-nationalist]] and [[Far-right politics|far-right]] extremist political organization in [[Japan]], which calls for an end to state welfare and alleged privileges afforded to [[Koreans in Japan|Zainichi Koreans]].{{cite news|last1=McCurry|first1=Justin|title=Police in Japan place anti-Zainichi Korean extremist group Zaitokukai on watchlist|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/04/police-japan-rightwing-anti-korean-extremist-group-zaitokukai-watchlist|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=The Guardian|date=4 December 2014}} It has been described by the [[National Police Agency (Japan)|National Police Agency]] as a potential threat to public order due to its "extreme nationalist and [[xenophobia|xenophobic]]" ideology. Its membership is between 9,000 to over 15,000.http://www.zaitokukai.info/ (Japanese) [[Vice News]] called them "J-racism's hottest new upstarts" in 2014,{{cite news|last1=Punk|first1=Olie|title=Japan's 'Internet Nationalists' Really Hate Koreans|url=https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/japan-racism-zaitokukai|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=[[Vice News]]|publisher=[[Vice Media]]|date=24 March 2014|quote=The post was recruiting activists for a counter protest against a right-wing group called Zaitokukai, J-racism's hottest new upstarts.}} and the group is considered by critics to be an anti-Korean extremist [[hate group]],{{cite news|last1=Quigley|first1=J. T.|title=Japanese Court Rules Against Anti-Korean Hate Group|url=http://thediplomat.com/2013/10/japanese-court-rules-against-anti-korean-hate-group/|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=The Diplomat|date=8 October 2013}}{{cite news|title=Rise of Hate Speech in Japan|url=http://www.hurights.or.jp/archives/focus/section2/2013/12/rise-of-hate-speech-in-japan.html|work=Asia-Pacific Human Rights Information Center|language=ja}} and have been compared to [[neo-Nazis]] in the [[western world]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/29/world/asia/29japan.html?ref=world |title=A New Wave of Dissent in Japan Is Openly and Loudly Anti-Foreign |last=Fackler |first=Martin |accessdate=28 August 2010 |quote=Though some here compare these groups to [[neo-Nazis]], [[sociologists]] say that they are different because they lack an aggressive ideology of racial supremacy. There have been no reports of injuries, or violence beyond pushing and shouting. Rather, the Net right’s main purpose seems to be venting frustration, both about Japan’s diminished stature and in their own personal economic difficulties. | publisher =[[The New York Times]] |date=August 28, 2010}} It was founded and led by a man who goes by the assumed name, [[Makoto Sakurai (Japanese writer)|Makoto Sakurai]]. On November 16, 2014, Yasuhiro Yagi was selected as chairman for the fifth term as the result of a vote of confidence by the group's members. http://www.zaitokukai.info/modules/news/article.php?storyid=639 (Japanese) ==History== ===Foundation=== Zaitokukai was founded on December 2, 2006, and held its inaugural meeting in January 2007.Makoto Sakurai, ''Daikenkanjidai'' (大嫌韓時代), Seirindo, 2014, p. 162. Sakurai founded Zaitokukai after seeing a TV news report about a group of Japanese citizens was organized to support Zainichi Koreans who brought a lawsuit to obtain national pensions without making any premium payments. Sakurai was disturbed by the fact that there were Japanese who backed a suit which he thought could destroy the Japanese pension system. He then searched for a conservative political organization fighting against what he regarded as an extraordinary demand of Zainichi Koreans, but could find none. He then decided to establish Zaitokukai.Ditto, pp. 159–160. ===Activities=== The group has been protesting against the extension of [[suffrage]] to foreign nationals. In September 2009, it held a demonstration in [[Akihabara]] calling for the resistance to granting suffrage to foreign nationals with about 1,000 participants, according to Sakurai himself.Makoto Sakurai, ''Zaitokukai toha “Zainichi Tokken o Yurusanai Shimin no Kai no Ryakusho desu!'' (在特会とは「在日特権を許さない市民の会」の略称です！) meaning “Zaitokukai is short for ‘Association of Citizens against the Special Privileges of the Zainichi!’”, Seirindo, 2013, p. 62. Some time before that, Zaitokukai held a counter-protest against a demonstration by more than 3,000 in [[Ginza, Tokyo]], organized by [[Mindan]] (the Korean Residents Union in Japan) to extend suffrage to foreigners.Ditto, p. 63. The group involves themselves extensively on [[social media]]. Several members of the group made donations to the political funding organization of [[Tomomi Inada]] between 2010 and 2012.[https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170602/p2a/00m/0na/007000c Supreme Court dismisses LDP's Inada's defamation suit against the Mainichi], ''The Mainichi'' (June 2 2017). ==Agenda== Zaitokukai alleges that Zainichi Koreans have special legal rights granted to them through the process of their integration into the Japanese society. It claims that members of this ethnic group use "pass names" that are Japanese-style and often very different from their original Korean names to abuse welfare and administrative systems. Members of the group also believe that it is much easier for Zainichi Koreans to claim and receive welfare benefits than it is for Japanese citizens, causing serious problems in the entire welfare system in Japan to the detriment of Japanese citizens. It accuses Zainichi Koreans of cheating the tax system as well, claiming that Zainichi Koreans pay reduced amounts for many taxes, including income tax, corporate tax, and council tax. It argues that Zainichi Koreans wrongfully claim those rights by saying that they are a deprived and discriminated minority in Japanese society.http://www.zaitokukai.info/modules/about/zai/promises.html In pursuit of its goals, Zaitokukai has set an ultimate goal of repealing the {{nihongo|Special Act on Immigration Control|入管特例法}} Formally “Special Act on the Immigration Control of, Inter Alia, Those Who Have Lost Japanese Nationality Pursuant to the Treaty of Peace with Japan” ([http://law.e-gov.go.jp/htmldata/H03/H03HO071.html 日本国との平和条約に基づき日本の国籍を離脱した者等の出入国管理に関する特例法]) (Japanese) which gives Zainichi Koreans [[Special Permanent Resident (Japan)|special permanent residence]] status which can never be granted to other foreign nationals. The first chairman Sakurai declared in his book that Zaitokukai would be dissolved when the Special Act on Immigration Control is repealed.Makoto Sakurai, ''Zaitokukai toha "Zainichi Tokken o Yurusanai Shimin no Kai" no Ryakusho desu!'' (在特会とは「在日特権を許さない市民の会」の略称です！) (which means ″Zaitokukai is short for ′Association of Citizens against the Special Privileges of the Zainichi!′″), Seirindo, 2013, p. 43. The second chairman, Yasuhiro Yagi, also affirmed in his inauguration message that Zaitokukai’s ultimate objective is to annul the said Act.[http://www.zaitokukai.info/modules/news/article.php?storyid=640 会長選挙当選の挨拶] (Japanese) ==Criticism== [[File:2013-06-30 しばき隊と有田芳生参議院議員 目線入り.jpg|thumb|right|Anti-Zaitokukai group facing off against the [[Riot Police Unit|Riot Police]] was provoking the Zaitokukai with [[the finger]]. Behind to the right is noted anti-racist activist [[Yoshifu Arita]] ]] [[File:Ultra-left activists protest against anti-Korean rally on 31 March 2013 at Shin-Okubo 02.JPG|thumb|right|Anti-Zaitokukai rally in Tokyo, 2013]] The group is criticized for its aggressive and racist behaviour towards non-citizen residents of Japan, mostly Zainichi Koreans. Its supporters have described Zainichi Koreans as "criminals" and "cockroaches", and called upon them to be killed. It frequently organizes small-scale public demonstrations against Zainichi Koreans and other social and political issues, and its members make racist insults against Koreans, Chinese, and other foreign nationals in these demonstrations.{{cite news| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/asia-pacific/a-black-sun-rises-in-a-declining-japan/article1744434/ | location=Toronto | work=The Globe and Mail | title=A black sun rises in a declining Japan | date=August 23, 2012}} A writer for ''Vice News'' pointed out they tend to focus on Zainichi Koreans to the exclusion of other groups that might violate immigration statutes. They also take to the Internet, and in August 2014, Lee Sin (variously named as Lee Shinhae and Lee Shin-hye), a Zainichi Korean freelance writer, filed two lawsuits, one for damages of ¥5.5 million against the group and Sakurai and ¥22 million against the administrator of Hoshu Shimpo, a conservative news website compiler for [[defamation]] by hate speech, the first of its kind. Ms. Lee received sometimes hundreds of negative messages daily on her social networking site and says that she would like to hold responsible website compiler that profits from compiling discriminatory internet commentary.Takahashi, Mei, "Damages Claimed for Hate Speech", Voices From Japan (Asia-Japan Women's Resource Center), No. 29 March 2015, p.49 Ikuo Gonoi, a professor at [[Takachiho University]] and researcher at the Institute of Social Science at [[International Christian University]], described them in 2013 as "just an archaic type of 'mob' (which [[Hannah Arendt]] defined in ''[[The Origins of Totalitarianism]]'', 1951), not something like a 'new wave{{'"}}.[http://astand.asahi.com/magazine/wrpolitics/2013060400011.html "Spreading hate speech: from revisionism to anti-semitism"], June 5, 2013, ''[[Asahi Shimbun|Astand]]'' {{ja icon}} == Incidents == In 2009 they showed up at the school and home of a Filipino girl whose parents were deported for overstaying their visas.http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2017/03/fukushima-gave-rise-anti-racism-movement-170310103716807.html In 2010 they protested showings of ''[[The Cove (film)|The Cove]].''https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/29/world/asia/29japan.html?ref=world&_r=1 On December 4, 2009, four members of Zaitokukai were arrested for harassing Korean students in [[Minami-ku, Kyoto|Minami Ward]], [[Kyoto]],{{cite news | url = http://www.asahi.com/english/TKY201008100352.html | title = Rightists arrested over harassment of schoolchildren | publisher = [[Asahi Shimbun]] | date = 2010-08-11 | accessdate = }}{{cite news | url = http://megalodon.jp/2010-0812-1101-26/mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20100810p2g00m0dm059000c.html | title = Several to be held for allegedly harassing Korean school | publisher = [[Mainichi Daily News]] | date = August 10, 2010 | accessdate = }} at a [[Chongryon|pro-DPRK]] school.{{cite web | url = http://the-diplomat.com/tokyo-notes/2010/08/12/rightists%E2%80%99-childish-attacks/ | title = Rightists’ Childish Attacks | last = Sharp | first = Andy | publisher = [[The Diplomat]] | date = August 12, 2010 | accessdate = August 29, 2010 }} On 17 June 2013, Makoto Sakurai and three other members were arrested in [[Shinjuku]], Tokyo, when a fistfight broke between counter-protesters and the Zaitokukai.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/18/world/asia/8-arrested-in-tokyo-fights-involving-anti-korean-group.html | work=The New York Times | first=Martin | last=Fackler | title=8 Arrested in Tokyo Fights Involving Anti-Korean Group | date=June 17, 2013}} In early 2014, their demonstration of 100 in [[Ikebukuro]] were met by double the number of counterprotesters. Sakurai's van was surrounded but managed to escape to Koreatown, and one member and four counterprotesters were arrested.https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/29/world/asia/29japan.html?ref=world&_r=1 ==See also== * [[Chongryon]] * [[Japan First Party]] * [[Ethnic issues in Japan]] * [[Japanese nationalism]] * [[Zainichi Korean]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Zaitokukai}} *{{official website|http://www.zaitokukai.info/}}{{ja icon}} *[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/community/2009/04/14/issues/a-battle-for-japans-future/#.U2dHM_l_u1M 'A battle for Japan's future'] [[The Japan Times]] *[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/29/world/asia/29japan.html New Dissent in Japan Is Loudly Anti-Foreign] [[The New York Times]] {{Racism topics |state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Japanese nationalism]] [[Category:Nationalist organizations]] [[Category:Anti-communist organizations in Japan]] [[Category:Far-right politics in Japan]] [[Category:Anti-Korean sentiment in Japan]] [[Category:Ethnic issues in Japan]]

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = George "Mojo" Buford | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = George Carter Buford, Jr. | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1929|11|10|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Hernando, Mississippi]], United States | death_date = {{death date and age|2011|10|11|1929|11|10|mf=y}} | death_place =[[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], United States | instrument = [[Harmonica]] | genre = [[Blues]] | occupation = | years_active = Early 1950s–2011 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = }}
'''George Carter Buford, Jr.''' (November 10, 1929 – October 11, 2011),<ref name="bare">{{cite book| first1= Bob| last1= Eagle| first2= Eric S.| last2= LeBlanc| year= 2013| title= Blues: A Regional Experience| publisher= Praeger| location= Santa Barbara, California| pages=228 | isbn= 978-0-313-34423-7}}</ref> known as '''Mojo Buford''', was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[harmonica]] player best known for his work in [[Muddy Waters]]'s band.
== Biography == Buford relocated from [[Hernando, Mississippi]], to [[Memphis, Tennessee]], in his youth, where he studied the blues.<ref name="AMG" /> He relocated to [[Chicago]] in 1952,<ref name="russell">{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books | location= Dubai | page= 96 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> forming the Savage Boys, which eventually was known as the Muddy Waters, Jr. Band. They substituted for Waters at local nightclubs while he was touring.<ref name="AMG" />
Buford first played in Waters's backing band in 1959, replacing [[Little Walter]], but in 1962 moved to [[Minneapolis]] to front his own band and to record albums.<ref name="AMG" /> In Minneapolis he gained the nickname Mojo, because of audiences requesting him to perform his [[cover version]] of "[[Got My Mojo Working]]."<ref name="MS">{{cite web|url=http://www.mswritersandmusicians.com/musicians/george-mojo-buford.html |title=George Mojo Buford, a Mississippi Musician |publisher=Mswritersandmusicians.com |date=1929-11-10 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> Buford returned to Waters's combo in 1967 for a year, replacing [[James Cotton]].<ref name="MS" /> He had a longer tenure with Waters in the early 1970s and returned for the final time after [[Jerry Portnoy]] departed to form the [[The Legendary Blues Band|Legendary Blues Band]].<ref name="AMG" />
He also recorded for the Mr. Blues label. These recordings were later reissued by [[Rooster Blues]], Blue Loon Records, and the British [[JSP Records|JSP]] label.<ref name="AMG" />
Buford died on October 11, 2011, at the age of 81, in Minneapolis, after a long hospitalization.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Skelly, Richard |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/george-mojo-buford-mn0000922782/biography |title=George "Mojo" Buford: Biography |publisher=AllMusic.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref><ref name="Amer">{{cite web |url=http://www.ameriblues.com/2011/10/11/mojo-buford-former-muddy-waters-harmonica-player-has-passed/ |title=Mojo Buford, Former Muddy Waters Harmonica Player, Has Passed |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Ameriblues.com |accessdate=October 11, 2011}}</ref>
== Discography == *''Exciting Harmonica Sound of Mojo Buford'', BluesRecordSoc, 1963 *''Mojo Buford's Chicago Blues Summit'', [[Rooster Blues]], 1979 *''State of the Blues Harp'', [[JSP Records|JSP]], 1989 *''Harpslinger'', Blue Loon, 1993 *''Still Blowin' Strong'' (Blue Loon, 1996) *''Home Is Where My Harps Is'', Blue Loon, 1998 *''Champagne & Reefer'', Fedora Records, 1999 *''Blues Ain't a Color'', Kpnbeat, 2005<ref name="Albums">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/george-mojo-buford-mn0000922782/discography |title=George 'Mojo' Buford: Discography |publisher=AllMusic.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>
== See also == *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] *[[List of harmonica blues musicians]] *[[List of harmonicists]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p60664/biography|pure_url=yes}} Biography at Allmusic.com]

{{italic title}} '''''The Romance of Chastisement''''' is a Victorian [[pornographic]] collection on the theme of [[flagellation]] by St George Stock (a probable [[pseudonym]], also credited with ''[[The Whippingham Papers]]'') and published by [[John Camden Hotten]] in 1866. It was reprinted by [[William Lazenby]] in 1883 and again by [[Charles Carrington]] in 1902 as ''The Magnetism of the Rod or the Revelations of Miss Darcy''.
==References== {{reflist}} * [[Henry Spencer Ashbee]] (as Pisanus Fraxi), "Bibliography of Forbidden Books", Volume 1, 1877, p.353 * [[John Sutherland (author)|John Sutherland]], "The Stanford Companion to Victorian Fiction", [[Stanford University Press]], 1990, {{ISBN|0-8047-1842-3}}, p.307. * Walter M. Kendrick, "The secret museum: pornography in modern culture", [[University of California Press]], 1996, {{ISBN|0-520-20729-7}}, p.168 * Sharon Marcus, "Between women: friendship, desire, and marriage in Victorian England", ''Princeton paperbacks'', [[Princeton University Press]], 2007, {{ISBN|0-691-12835-9}}, p.145 * Joanne Shattock, "The Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature:, Volume 4; Volumes 1800-1900", [[Cambridge University Press]], 2000, {{ISBN|0-521-39100-8}}, p.1905 * Lisa Z. Sigel, ''International Exposure: Perspectives on Modern European Pornography, 1800-2000'' (Rutgers University Press, 2005), {{ISBN|0-8135-3519-0}}, pp.73-74,95-96
{{DEFAULTSORT:Romance of Chastisement}} [[Category:British pornography]] [[Category:1866 short story collections]] [[Category:BDSM literature]]
{{story-collection-stub}}

{{Infobox bodybuilder |image=Elena_Panova_in_2008.jpg | | name = Elena Panova | image_size = | caption = Elena Panova 2008 Championship | nickname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|04|26}} | birth_place = [[Voronezh]], [[Russia]] | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{height|ft=5|in=4}} | weight = (In Season) 136-138 lbs.
(Off-Season) 174-176 lbs. | firstproshow = FBFR Southern Russia Third Championship | firstproshowyear = 2003 | bestwin = WFF-WBBF World Pro Championship - 2nd place | bestwinyear = 2007, 2008 | yesorretiredyear = Since 2003 }} '''Yelena A Panova''', often '''Elena Panova''' ({{lang-rus|Елена Александровна Панова}}; born April 26, 1979) is a [[female bodybuilding|female bodybuilder]] from [[Voronezh]], [[Russia]]{{cite news | author= ironworld.ru| url= http://www.ironworld.ru/athletes/bb/5394/?phrase_id=323898/| title= Elena Panova | language = Russian}} ==Background== Elena graduated from the Voronezh State Technical University with a master's degree in Public Relations. She began training to lose weight in 1998. Generally it was step aerobics at that time. Elena decided to become a bodybuilder after attending a local bodybuilding contest where she got a very good impression of the competitors. She was also inspired by the magazines with well-known female bodybuilders as [[Lenda Murray]], [[Cory Everson]] and [[Juliette Bergmann]] on their covers. In 2004 Elena changed her career and became a personal trainer. In winter 2006 Elena moved to [[Moscow]] and worked there at one of the leading fitness center.[http://www.getfit.ru/clubs/news/news_1823.html]. In 2009 Elena moves to [[Miami]] ([[Florida]], [[US]]) and lives there up to the present moment. Married, no children. ==Bodybuilding career== In 2003 Elena competed in her first contest FBFR Southern Russia Third Championship "Samson 22", finishing in sixth place.{{cite news | author= samson-gym.ru| url= http://www.samson-gym.ru/sams22.html | title= Samson 22 Protocol | language = Russian}} In 2004 Panova suffered a car crash injury and was not able to train and compete for a year. In 2005, she took second place at the WFF-WBBF Russia Amateur Championship. In 2006 Elena earned her professional status at WFF-WBBF Europe Pro Championship, finishing in fourth place. Her greatest success as a professional has been the second place at the WFF-WBBF World Pro Championship 2007 and 2008. After 2009 WFF-WBBF Pro World Championships Elena Panova holds fourth position in World Professional Ranking List (Women).{{cite news | author= wff.lt| url= http://www.wff.lt/page.php?lang=en&idd=rei&id=26 | title= WFF-WBBF 2009 Professional Ranking List (Women)}} ==Contest history== *2003 FBFR Southern Russia Third Championship "Samson 22" - 6th *2005 WFF-WBBF Russia Amateur Championship - 2nd. *2006 WFF-WBBF Europe Amateur Championship – 2nd.{{cite news | author= wff.lt| url= http://www.wff.lt/page.php?lang=en&idd=eur&id=24 | title= 2006 WFF-WBBF Europe Amateur Championship Protocol}} *2006 WFF-WBBF Europe Pro Championship - 4th *2007 WFF-WBBF Europe Pro Championship - 2nd.{{cite news | author= wff.lt| url= http://www.wff.lt/page.php?lang=en&idd=pro&id=14 | title= 2007 WFF-WBBF Europe Pro Championship Protocol}} *2007 WFF-WBBF World Amateur Championship - 1st.{{cite news | author= wff.lt| url= http://www.wff.lt/page.php?lang=en&idd=pas&id=21 | title= 2007 WFF-WBBF World Amateur Championship Protocol}} *2007 WFF-WBBF World Pro Championship - 2nd.{{cite news | author= wff.lt| url= http://www.wff.lt/page.php?lang=en&idd=pro&id=17 | title= 2007 WFF-WBBF World Pro Championship Protocol}} *2008 WFF-WBBF World Pro Championship - 2nd.{{cite news | author= wff.lt| url= http://www.wff.lt/page.php?lang=en&idd=pro&id=27 | title= 2008 WFF-WBBF World Pro Championship Protocol}} *2011 NPC FL Gold Cup November 12 - Women Overall - 1st, Women Heavyweight - 1st, Women Masters Overall - 1st, Women Masters 30+ - 1st.{{cite news | author= rxmuscle.com| url= http://gallery.rxmuscle.com/index.php?contest=261&year=470 | title = 2011 NPC FL Gold Cup November 12 Protocol}} {{hide in print|1= ==Image gallery== {{Gallery | lines = 2 |File:IMG 5647-1-print.jpg|Elena Panova at the WFF Pro Championship (2008), Posing. |File:Elena Panova Photo Session.jpg|Elena Panova (2008), Photo Session - ''Photo: Andrey Krutogolov''. }}}} ==References== {{reflist|}} ==External links== *[http://gallery.rxmuscle.com/index.php?bodybuilder=24321 2011 NPC FL Gold Cup Gallery] *[http://el-panova.narod.ru/ Personal WebPage] {{ru icon}} *[http://www.alleyasporta.ru/article/view/303/&page_1 Alleya Sporta Magazine Exclusive Interview with Elena Panova] {{ru icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Panova, Elena}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian female bodybuilders]] {{Russia-sport-bio-stub}} {{bodybuilding-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Paintings */Replaced "Rear Guard" with "Rearguard". It is one word.
revision.text:
'''James Princip Beadle''' (1863–1947), was an [[English people|English]] painter of historical and military scenes. Born in [[Calcutta]] on 22 September 1863, his father was [[Major-General]] James Pattle Beadle. For three years, he studied with [[Legros]] at the [[Slade School]] in London and at the [[Ecole des Beaux Arts]] in Paris under [[Alexandre Cabanel]]; his final studies were back in London with [[G.F. Watts]].
==Painting career==
Beadle first exhibited at the [[Royal Academy]] in 1884 and also at the Paris Salon. Five years later, he was awarded a bronze medals at the Paris [[World's fair|Exposition Universelle]]. Growing up in a military family, the artist was particularly attracted to military subjects and one of his earliest pieces depicted the inspection of the [[Duke of Yorks Own Loyal Suffolk Hussars]] at Bury St. Edmonds in 1893. From then on, he was a frequent exhibitor of 'battle' paintings at the RA, the New Gallery and elsewhere. In a review published in the [[Illustrated London News]] on 19 May 1894, Beadle's military pieces were singled-out for praise: "He does not go out of his way to flatter 'Tommy Atkins', but he shows him to the public under many forms and in many becoming uniforms. He has studied him at home and abroad, at peace and at war, on horseback and on foot..."
While many of his scenes represented contemporary events such as the [[Franco-Prussian War]], the [[Boer War]] and the [[First World War]], Beadle found the subject of the [[Peninsular War]], particularly interesting and visited Spain and Portugal in 1912 to sketch the battlefields.<ref>A number of his pencil sketches drawn during this trip are reproduced in Willoughby Verner's 'History and Campaigns of the Rifle Brigade'.</ref> As late as 1924, the artist was still paintings scenes from the [[Peninsular War]], but the events of 1914-1918 were also occupying his mind, and several notable paintings were produced including ''Neuve Chapelle, 10 March 1915'', ''Dawn: Waiting to go over'', and ''Breaking the Hindenburg Line''. In his final years, he lived in [[Kensington]] and died at his home on Eldon Road on 13 August 1947, leaving his widow, A.M.G. Beadle.
==Paintings== * ''George II knighting Trooper Brown'' ([[Queen's Royal Hussars]]) * ''The Rearguard'' (Retreat to Corunna) ([[The Rifles]]) * ''Sahagun, December 1808'' ([[The Light Dragoons]]) * ''Vitoria, June 21, 1813: The Village of Gamara Mayor carried by the 4th, 47th and 59th Regiments of General Robinson's Brigade'' ([[Nuneaton]] Art Gallery) * ''St. Sebastian, August 1813'' (Regimental Museum, [[King's Own Royal Regiment]], [[Lancaster, Lancashire|Lancaster]]) * ''Salamanca'' (Regimental Museum, [[King's Own Royal Regiment]], [[Lancaster, Lancashire|Lancaster]]) * ''The Passage of the Bidassoa by Wellington's Army, Oct. 7th, 1813'' (1908 - [[Queen's Royal Hussars]]) * ''Napoleon's last inspection at Waterloo'' * ''"1815." The Captive Eagle. Corporal Styles of the Royal Dragoons, etc'' (1892 - [[Norfolk]] Museums Service) * ''Saving the Guns at Maiwand'' (1893 - [[National Army Museum]]) * ''The Victors of Paardeberg'' * ''The Empty Saddle: South Africa, 1900'' ([[Queen's Royal Lancers]]) * ''Bergendal, South Africa: Charge of the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade'' (1914 - [[The Rifles]]) * ''Battle of Gheluveldt, 31 October 1914'' (1920 - [[Worcester]] Museum and Art Gallery) * ''Dawn: Waiting to go over'' ([[Imperial War Museum]]) * ''Neuve Chapelle, 10 March 1915: 2nd Rifle Brigade and 39th Garwal Rifles clearing the village'' ([[Maidstone]] Museum & Art Gallery) * ''Battle of the Somme: Attack of the Ulster Division, 1 July 1916'' ([[Belfast]] City Hall) * ''Breaking the Hindenburg Line'' ([[Imperial War Museum]]) * ''The Lost Patrol (East Riding Yeomanry in Palestine, 1917'' ([[Queen's Own Yeomanry]], [[York]]) * ''The Action of the 6th Mounted Brigade (The Bucks, Berks and Dorset Yeomanry) at El Mughar'' (1922 - Crown Commissioners, Institute of Directors, Pall Mall) * ''Charge of the Bucks, Berks, and Dorset Yeomanry at El Mughar, Palestine Campaign, 13 November 1917'' (1936 - [[Staff College, Camberley]])

{{Primary sources|date=November 2010}} The '''Mars Exploration Program Analysis Group''' ('''MEPAG''') is a forum created by [[NASA]] to enable the scientific community to provide input for the planning and prioritizing of the [[exploration of Mars]] over the next several decades.
The other forums created are the [[Moon|Lunar]] Exploration Analysis Group (LEAG), the [[Outer planets|Outer Planets]] Assessment Group (OPAG), the [[Small Solar System body|Small Bodies]] Assessment Group (SBAG), and the [[Venus]] Exploration Analysis Group (VEXAG).
== See also == *[[Mars Exploration Program]]
== External links == * [http://mepag.jpl.nasa.gov/ MEPAG Official Website]

page.title: Wikipedia:Peer review/School for Creative and Performing Arts/archive1

revision.text:
===[[Wikipedia:Peer review/School for Creative and Performing Arts/archive1|School for Creative and Performing Arts]]=== {{Peer review tools|School for Creative and Performing Arts}} :{{PR/heading|School for Creative and Performing Arts| Wikipedia:Peer review/School for Creative and Performing Arts/archive1|December 2009}} '''This peer review discussion has been closed.'''
[[Category:January 2010 peer reviews]] I've listed this article for peer review because I've considerably expanded the article and would like to receive suggestions on how to improve this article up to GA standards. Thanks, [[User:Vaughanchris|Vaughanchris]] ([[User talk:Vaughanchris|talk]]) 21:18, 16 December 2009 (UTC) '''Comments by doncram''' First, it seems to me that the article should be moved to "School for Creative and Performing Arts (Cincinnati, Ohio)", to add the disambiguating and clarifying parenthetical phrase. Google search turns up similarly named schools in San Diego and Pittsburgh; the San Diego one uses "of" rather than "for". The current title "School for Creative and Performing Arts" seems like a non-unique name, and it seems possibly a tad Ohio-centric to assert, implicitly, that the use of the preposition "for" is to be understood by the world to mean the Cincinnati school. I notice also that [[School of Creative and Performing Arts]] is currently a redirect to this page; it could/should be made into a disambiguation page listing all instead. Or, is this SCPA that famous, nation- or world-wide, that it is really an obvious primary use for the phrase? Second, the article seems perhaps more detailed than necessary, and perhaps more promotional in tone. For example, that "The college-preparatory curriculum includes language arts, foreign language, mathematics, science, and social studies" seems unsurprising and not different than what most high U.S. high schools cover. That "Advanced Placement courses are available in many of these subjects. The school serves students will all academic needs, including those with special needs." seems to be relevant for a school brochure for prospective students and their parents, but not necessary for a wikipedia article. I notice one sentence needing clarification: "SCPA has historically been among the highest-scoring public schools, second only to Walnut Hills High School, the selective public college preparatory magnet.[5]" Among the highest-scoring out of what set, schools in Ohio, the nation, the world? Hope these quick comments are helpful. [[User:Doncram|doncram]] ([[User talk:Doncram|talk]]) 22:04, 22 December 2009 (UTC) :Addendum: Actually maybe the school is that famous, and should stay at the current article title. I am just not familiar with it. Also, i did start a disambiguation page at [[School of Creative and Performing Arts]]. :I wonder about another claim, that this is "the first and only school to combine a full range of arts studies with a rigorous academic program for elementary through high school". The only school in the world? I am sure that depends on how you define "a full range" and "rigorous". I'd be more comfortable if a broad claim like that was presented as a quotation from a source. If it's the school's own assertion, it can still be given, but it should be identified clearly as being their own claim. [[User:Doncram|doncram]] ([[User talk:Doncram|talk]]) 22:27, 22 December 2009 (UTC) ::Further about the disambiguation issues, i developed the disambiguation page further and just found [[School for the Creative and Performing Arts]] about a Kentucky school, whose wikipedia article started in 2006. I note a discussion section at the Cleveland school's talk page on the issue, previously, too. I'll open a requested move about renaming both of these two school wikipedia pages, to address that. About other matters in this article, perhaps someone else will give more comments. I may not comment further myself, esp. in the absence of some response about my comments so far though. [[User:Doncram|doncram]] ([[User talk:Doncram|talk]]) 11:14, 23 December 2009 (UTC) :Thank you for your review and comments. I've made additional edits per your suggestions, and I agree they improve the article. Regarding the renaming question, I think it is a valid discussion and I have commented on the talk page. [[User:Vaughanchris|Vaughanchris]] ([[User talk:Vaughanchris|talk]]) 16:55, 24 December 2009 (UTC)

revision.text:
<!-- This article is a part of [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Aircraft]]. Please see [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Aircraft/page content]] for recommended layout. --> {|{{Infobox aircraft begin | name= Pfitzner Flyer | image=PfitznerFlyer Threequarter front view CC flickr.jpg | caption= }}{{Infobox aircraft type | type= [[Experimental aircraft|Experimental]] pusher monoplane | national origin= [[United States]] | manufacturer= [[Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company]] | designer= [[Alexander Pfitzner]] | first flight=January 1910 | introduced= | retired= | status= | primary user= Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company | number built=1 | developed from= | variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Pfitzner Flyer''' was an innovative [[monoplane]] designed in 1909 by [[Alexander Pfitzner]] and built by the [[Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company|Curtiss]] company at [[Hammondsport]], [[New York (state)|NY]], where Pfitzner was employed at the time.
The Flyer was the first [[monoplane]] designed, built and flown in the [[United States]].<ref name=NYT_19100116/> It incorporated several novel features, the most innovative of which was the method of achieving lateral control by means of reciprocating lateral ([[Telescoping (mechanics)|telescopic]]) wing extensions, which the pilot controlled via a steering wheel. Also unusual for a monoplane was the use of a [[pusher configuration]], the engine also being mounted behind the pilot.<ref name=Loening_p134/>
The aircraft was not a success, and a disappointed Pfitzner is thought to have committed suicide on 12 July 1910.<ref name=Flight_II(30)>''Flight'' Magazine II (30), p. 584.</ref><ref name=Villard>Villard (2002), p.216.</ref>
==Background== Since their success with the first recorded powered flight, the [[Wright Brothers]] had patented many of their methods and had sought to enforce their patents through the courts.<ref name=Ashby>Ashby (2002), p.5.</ref> Most if not all other manufacturers were keen to develop alternative techniques; Pfitzner avoided the Wrights' method of [[Wing warping|warping]] the wings to achieve a lift differential between port and starboard wings by using wing extensions (or 'compensators'), described below. In his book “Monoplanes and Biplanes: Their Design, Construction and Operation” (1911), [[Grover Loening]] wrote “This aeroplane is a distinct departure from all other monoplanes in the placing of the motor, aviator, and rudders, and in the comparatively simple and efficient method of transverse control by sliding surfaces, applied here for the first time.”.<ref name=Loening_p134>Loening (1911), p.134.</ref> The issue of patent protection was sufficiently in the public eye for ''[[The New York Times]]'', in its issue of 16 January 1910, to headline Pfitzner’s design as an “Aeroplane Without Patent Drawbacks".<ref name=NYT_19100116/> The same article refers to the “Wright suits” and their attempts to “build up their patent fences”; Pfitzner is quoted there as saying that “any one who wants to do so is welcome to use <nowiki>[his]</nowiki> panel invention without cost or fear of injunction”.<ref name=NYT_19100116>''New York Times'' ([https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/01/16/105073520.pdf NYT 16 Jan. 1910])</ref>
==Design and development== Pfitzner, a “designer of high-class gasoline motors, transmissions, and gears” <ref name=NYT_19100116/> was employed by Glen Curtiss at his Hammondsport factory. Pfitzner designed his ''Flyer'' as a private project but it was constructed in the Curtiss factory.<ref name=Flight_II(11)/>
The aircraft consisted of a [[Cuboid#Rectangular cuboid|rectangular cuboid]] [[Cross bracing|cross-braced]] central frame, onto which the main monoplane wing, the motor, the forward and rear booms and the ‘undercarriage’ (consisting of one wheel at each of the lower corners) were mounted. Between the upper front and rear posts of the frame were fitted two streamlined fuel tanks (clearly visible in the image above), one on each side of and above the pilot’s seat, with a combined capacity of six gallons (22.7 L.).<ref name=Flight_II(9)/>
[[File:PfitznerFlyer Control linkage FlightGlobalVoll II(9) p.182.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Diagram showing aircraft control linkages between control column and various control surfaces|Image first published in ''Flight'' Vol. II(11) in 1910, from Flight Global archive]]
The pilot sat immediately forward of the wing and controlled the aircraft by a combination a movable column and a wheel mounted on that column. Pitch was controlled by fore and aft movement of the column, which, by means of wires, moved the elevator mounted at the forward end of the front boom. Yaw control was effected by twisting the column about its vertical axis (by means of pressure on the steering wheel), which turned the vertical rudder (mounted above the elevator) left or right. Lateral control was achieved by rotating the wheel: When the pilot turned the steering-wheel to port, the linkage (shown below and here<ref name=Flight_II(11)>''Flight'' II (11), p. 182.</ref>) retracted the port wingtip, at the same time extending the starboard extension by the same amount. Thus there was no need for a rudder bar (or pedals); the pilot’s feet were not used for controlling the aircraft. Also mounted on the control column was a throttle lever; a button on the wheel enabled "the Bosch high-tension magneto to be switched off for the purpose of switching off the engine". There was a fixed tail-plane surface with an area of 10.5 sq.ft. (0.98 sq.m.) at the end of the rear boom to provide longitudinal stability.<ref name=Flight_II(11)/> [[File:PfitznerFlyer Front view of wing trussing Flight Vol.II(11) FlightGlobal archive.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Image of early aircraft from the front showing king posts and trusses supporting the wings|Image first published in ''Flight'' Vol. II(11) in 1910, from Flight Global archive]]
The span of the main wing, which was set at an angle for incidence of 8°, was 31 ft., with a wingtip extension of {{convert|30|in|cm|abbr=on}} on each wing, providing a constant wingspan of 33 ft. 6 in. (10.21 m). The wing was 6 ft. (1.8 m) wide; the extensible wingtips were 4 ft. 2 in. (1,27 m) wide, each providing a maximum of 10.5 sq. ft. (0.98 sq.m.) wing area. The wing extensions were of the same curvature as the main wing.<ref name=Flight_II(11)/> “The main supporting plane at a 5-deg. dihedral angle consists of two main beams across which are placed spruce ribs. The surface is made of Baldwin vulcanized silk, of jet black color, tacked to the top of the ribs and laced to the frame. The curvature of the surface is slight and is designed for high speed.” <ref name=Loening_p134/> The wing ribs had a camber of 3.75 in. (9.05 cm) over 6 ft (1.8 m).<ref name=Flight_II(11)/>
Each of the wings consists of three detachable sections, each 5 ft. (1.5 m.) long, which are supported by steel sockets and steel cable, the latter forming a symmetrical double king truss with the beams, fore and aft pairs of [[King post]]s being situated at the junctions of the sections.<ref name=Flight_II(11)/>
==Operational history== Pfitzner himself, although an inexperienced flyer at the time,<ref name=Loening_p134/> conducted initial test flights with his ''Flyer'', the first taking place in early January 1910. Despite the presence of a light covering of snow at the time, it was reported that the ''Flyer'' had made a large number of short flights and that it required an average run of 100 ft. (30 m) to get airborne.<ref name=Flight_II(9)>''Flight'' II (9), p.142.</ref>
Following Pfitzner’s disappearance (and assumed suicide) in July, 1910, Horace K. Kearney took over the aircraft and demonstrated it at [[Fly-in|aero meets]] in the succeeding months, including in [[Boston]], before the ''Pfitzner Flyer'' became little more than an interesting footnote in the history of aviation.<ref name="thecrimson">{{Cite web|url = http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1910/9/27/aeronautical-society-meet-pone-of-the/|title = AERONAUTICAL SOCIETY MEET At Field in Squantum, September 3–13|accessdate = 2009-12-16|last = The Harvard Crimson|authorlink = |date=September 1910}}</ref>
==Specification== {{Aircraft specs |ref=<ref name=Ferris>{{cite book|last=Ferris|first=Richard|title=How it flies; or, The conquest of the air; the story of man's endeavors to fly and of the inventions by which he has succeeded|year=1910|publisher=T Nelson & sons|location=New York|url=https://archive.org/details/cu31924022830628}}</ref>{{rp|134–136}}{{Additional citation needed|date=November 2010}} |prime units?=imp<!-- imp or kts first for US aircraft, and UK aircraft pre-metrification, met(ric) first for all others. You MUST choose a format, or no specifications will show --> <!-- General characteristics --> |genhide= |crew=1 |capacity= |length m= |length ft=30 |length in= |length note= |span m= |span ft=33 |span in=6 |span note=(The main span was 31 ft, with extensions providing additional 2 ft. 6 in.) |height m= |height ft=7 |height in= |height note= |wing area sqm= |wing area sqft=196.5 |wing area note= (Area of main wing: 186 sq. ft. (17.3 sq.m.); area of each wingtip extension 10.5 sq. ft.(0.98 sq.m.)) |aspect ratio=5.17 : 1<!-- sailplanes --> |airfoil= |empty weight kg= |empty weight lb= |empty weight note= |gross weight kg= |gross weight lb=430 |gross weight note=(Gross weight includes 6 gallons of petrol, 1 gallon of oil and 1.5 gallons of water.) |max takeoff weight kg= |max takeoff weight lb=600 |max takeoff weight note= |fuel capacity= |more general= <!-- Powerplant --> |eng1 number=1 |eng1 name=Curtiss |eng1 type=4-cyl. petrol engine |eng1 kw=<!-- prop engines --> |eng1 hp=25<!-- prop engines --> |eng1 kn=<!-- jet/rocket engines --> |eng1 lbf=<!-- jet/rocket engines --> |eng1 note= |power original= |thrust original=235 lb. at 1,200 r.p.m. |prop blade number=2<!-- propeller aircraft --> |prop name= |prop dia m=<!-- propeller aircraft --> |prop dia ft=6<!-- propeller aircraft --> |prop dia in=<!-- propeller aircraft --> |prop note=
<!-- Performance --> |perfhide= |max speed kmh= |max speed mph=42 |max speed kts= |max speed note= |max speed mach=<!-- supersonic aircraft --> |cruise speed kmh= |cruise speed mph= |cruise speed kts= |cruise speed note= |stall speed kmh=<!-- aerobatic --> |stall speed mph=<!-- aerobatic --> |stall speed kts= |stall speed note= |never exceed speed kmh= |never exceed speed mph= |never exceed speed kts= |never exceed speed note= |minimum control speed kmh= |minimum control speed mph= |minimum control speed kts= |minimum control speed note= |range km= |range miles= |range nmi= |range note= |endurance=<!-- if range unknown --> |ceiling m= |ceiling ft= |ceiling note= |g limits=<!-- aerobatic --> |roll rate=<!-- aerobatic --> |glide ratio=<!-- sailplanes --> |climb rate ms= |climb rate ftmin= |climb rate note= |time to altitude= |lift to drag= |wing loading kg/m2 |wing loading lb/sqft=3.2 |wing loading note= |power/mass= |thrust/weight= |more performance= }}

revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Dunn Loring station]]

'''Erdem Moralioglu''' is a Canadian and Turkish fashion designer. He was born in [[Montreal, Quebec]], Canada to a [[Turkish people|Turkish]] father and an [[English people|English]] mother and grew up between Montreal and [[Birmingham, England]]. He earned a B.A. in fashion from [[Ryerson University]] in [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada and then worked as an intern for [[Vivienne Westwood]]. Erdem moved to [[London, England|London]] in 2000 to study fashion at the [[Royal College of Art]]. Upon receiving his master's degree in 2003, he went on to close the 2003 RCA show with his graduate collection. He then moved to [[New York City|New York]] where he worked alongside [[Diane von Fürstenberg]] before relocating back to London to launch his own label, ERDEM, in 2005.
==ERDEM brand== Known for his use of experimental textiles, vibrant prints, and detailed craftsmanship, ERDEM mixes the delicate with the bold.
ERDEM has received numerous accolades over the years, including the 2008 [[British Fashion Council]]’s Fashion Forward Award; the 2010 inaugural Vogue / British Fashion Council Designer Fashion Fund Award, the 2012 British Fashion Council’s New Establishment Award, the 2013 British Fashion Council’s Red Carpet Award, the 2014 British Fashion Council’s Womenswear Designer of the Year Award and most recently the 2015 British Fashion Council’s Establishment Designer award.
ERDEM is sold in over 170 of the most exclusive retailers, including Barneys New York, Bergdorf Goodman, Lane Crawford, Colette, Dover Street Market, Selfridges and Harvey Nichols. After launching an e-commerce store in 2014, the label opened its debut [https://erdem.com/store/ flagship store] in London’s Mayfair in August 2015.
==Notable clients== His clothes have been worn by actors [[Cate Blanchett]], [[Marion Cotillard]], [[Michelle Williams (actress)|Michelle Williams]], [[Gwyneth Paltrow]], [[Emma Watson]], [[Julianne Moore]], [[Anne Hathaway]], [[Alicia Vikander]], [[Keira Knightley]], [[Rashida Jones]], [[Emma Stone]], [[Linda Evangelista]], [[Jessica Chastain]] and [[Sarah Jessica Parker]] amongst others. In addition, the [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Duchess of Cambridge]] and the [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex|Countess of Wessex]] have worn the brand in several public outings. Most recently [[Royal Ballet]] Principal dancer [[Lauren Cuthbertson]] wore an ERDEM dress to the 2015 [[Laurence Olivier Awards]]. Actress [[Meghan Markle]] wore a £1,200 floral print ERDEM maxi dress when she attended a wedding with [[Prince Harry]] in March 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4284312/Harry-Meghan-REAL-story-Jamaican-reunion.html|title=Harry and Meghan...the REAL story of their romantic Jamaican reunion|work=Mail Online|access-date=2017-03-06}}</ref>
==Awards== Moralioglu has received numerous prestigious awards including:
• 2005: Fashion Fringe Award
• 2007: The Swarovski/British Fashion Council Fashion Enterprise Award
• 2008: The BFC's Fashion Forward Award
• 2009: Fashion Future Award
• 2010: British Fashion Council/Vogue Designer Fashion Fun Award and Elle Style Awards, ‘Designer of the Year’
• 2011: WGSN Global Fashion Awards, ‘Most Influential Designer’
• 2012: British Fashion Council New Establishment Award
• 2013: British Fashion Council Red Carpet Award and WGSN Womenswear Designer of the Year Award
• 2014: British Fashion Council ‘Womenswear of the Year’ Award
• 2015: ‘Designer of the Year’ at Canadian Arts & Fashion and UK Elle Style Awards.
• 2015: British Fashion Council 'Establishment Designer' award.
He was also nominated by the British Fashion Council for "Designer of the Year 2009" and was named one of the 1000 most influential people in London by the Evening Standard.
==Personal life== He currently lives and operates a studio in [[Bethnal Green]], east [[London]].<ref>{{cite news|author=The Independent|title=Star in the making: Designer Erdem Moralioglu |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/star-in-the-making-designer-erdem-moralioglu-930495.html|accessdate=2011-02-27|location=London|date=15 September 2008}}</ref> Moralioglu has a twin sister, Sara, who makes TV documentaries about geography and natural history.<ref>{{cite web |author=Style |title=Erdem |url=http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/F2010RTW-ERDEM |accessdate=2011-02-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110316020855/http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/F2010RTW-ERDEM/ |archivedate=2011-03-16 |df= }}</ref>
== References == <references/>
