{{Starbox begin | name = Gliese 1214 }} {{Starbox image | image = [[File:Morgan-Keenan spectral classification zoom.png|250px|center]] | caption = Gliese 1214 is a [[M dwarf|M-class]] dwarf star }} {{Starbox observe | epoch = J2000 | ra = {{RA|17|15|18.942}}<ref name="Skrutskie2006"/> | dec = {{DEC|+04|57|49.69}}<ref name="Skrutskie2006"/> | appmag_v = {{val|14.71|0.03}}<ref name="Berta2011"/> | constell = [[Ophiuchus]]<ref name="Roman1987"/> }} {{Starbox character | class = [[Stellar classification#Class M|M4.5]]<ref name="Rojas-Ayala2010"/> | appmag_1_passband = B | appmag_1 = 16.40<ref name="SIMBAD"/> | appmag_2_passband = R | appmag_2 = 13.8<ref name="SIMBAD"/> | appmag_3_passband = I | appmag_3 = 11.52 ± 0.03<ref name="Berta2011"/> | appmag_4_passband = J | appmag_4 = {{val|9.750|0.024}}<ref name="Skrutskie2006"/> | appmag_5_passband = H | appmag_5 = {{val|9.094|0.024}}<ref name="Skrutskie2006"/> | appmag_6_passband = K | appmag_6 = {{val|8.782|0.020}}<ref name="Skrutskie2006"/> | b-v = 1.73<ref name="van Altena1995"/> | v-r = 0.9 | r-i = 2.7 | variable = [[planetary transit variable|planetary transit]]<ref name="Charbonneau2009"/> }} {{Starbox astrometry | radial_v = +{{val|21.1|1.0}}<ref name="Berta2011"/> | prop_mo_ra = 585<ref name="Lépine2005"/> | prop_mo_dec = -752<ref name="Lépine2005"/> | parallax = 68.71 | p_error = 0.6 | parallax_footnote = <ref name="Anglada-Escudé2012"/> | absmag_v = 14.10 }} {{Starbox detail | mass = {{val|0.157|0.019}}<ref name="Charbonneau2009"/> | radius = {{val|0.2064|+0.0086|-0.0096}}<ref name="Berta2011"/> | luminosity = {{val|0.00328}}<ref name="Charbonneau2009"/> | temperature = {{val|3026|130}}<ref name="Charbonneau2009"/> | metal = {{val|0.39|0.15}}<ref name="Rojas-Ayala2010"/> | rotation = >25 days<ref name="Berta2011"/> | rotational_velocity = | gravity = {{val|4.991|0.029}}<ref name="Charbonneau2009"/> | age_gyr = 5−10<ref name=Lalitha2014/> }} {{Starbox catalog | names=[[Luyten Half-Second catalogue|LHS]] 3275, G 139-21, NLTT 44431, 2MASS J17151894+0457496, LSPM J1715+0457, UBV M 53793, USNO-B1.0 0949-00280047, GEN# +9.80139021.<ref name="SIMBAD"/> }} {{Starbox reference | Simbad= LHS+3275 | NSTED= GJ+1214 | ARICNS= 02203 | EPE= GJ+1214 }} {{Starbox end}} '''[[Gliese Catalogue of Nearby Stars|Gliese]] 1214''' is a dim [[Stellar classification#Class M|M4.5]]<ref name="Rojas-Ayala2010"/> [[red dwarf]] in the constellation [[Ophiuchus]] with an [[apparent magnitude]] of 14.7.<ref name="Berta2011"/> It is located at a distance of approximately 47 light years from [[Earth]].<ref name="Anglada-Escudé2012"/> The star is about one-fifth the radius of the [[Sun]]<ref name="harvardpress"/> with a surface temperature estimated to be {{convert|3000|K|comma=gaps}}.<ref name="harvardpress"/> Its luminosity is only 0.003% that of the Sun.<ref name="harvardpress"/>
The estimate for the stellar radius is 15% larger than predicted by theoretical models.<ref name="Charbonneau2009"/> It also shows a 1% intrinsic variability in the near-infrared probably caused by [[Starspot|stellar spots]].<ref name="Berta2011"/> The star is rotating slowly, with a period that is most likely an integer multiple of 53 days. It is probably at least three billion years old and a member of the old disk.<ref name="Berta2011"/> Although GJ 1214 has a low to moderate level of [[magnetic activity]], it does undergo [[stellar flare|flares]] and is a source of [[X-ray astronomy|X-ray emission]] with a base luminosity of {{Val|7.4e25|u=erg s<sup>−1</sup>}}. The temperature of the [[corona]] is estimated to be about {{Val|3.5e6|u=K}}.<ref name=Lalitha2014/>
==Planetary system==
In mid-December 2009, a team of Harvard-Smithsonian astronomers announced the discovery of a companion [[extrasolar planet]], [[Gliese 1214 b]], potentially composed largely of water and having the mass and diameter of a [[super-Earth]].<ref name="Charbonneau2009"/><ref name="harvardpress"/>
{{OrbitboxPlanet begin | table_ref =<ref name="Berta2011"/><ref name="Charbonneau2009"/> }} {{OrbitboxPlanet | exoplanet = [[Gliese 1214 b|b]] | mass_earth = 6.55 ± 0.98 | radius_earth = 2.64 ± 0.13 | semimajor = 0.0143 ± 0.0019 | inclination = 88.17 | period = 1.58040456 ± 1.6x10<sup>−7</sup><ref name="Harpsøe">{{cite journal |author=Kennet B. W. Harpsøe |display-authors=etal |journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics |title=The Transiting System Gliese 1214 |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201219996 |arxiv=1207.3064 |date=2012 |bibcode=2013A&A...549A..10H |volume=549 |pages=A10 }}</ref>
| eccentricity = <0.27 }} {{Orbitbox end}}
[[Image:GJ1214b (Artist’s impression).jpg|thumb|alt=The newly discovered super-Earth surrounding the nearby star GJ 1214.|This artist’s impression shows how the newly discovered super-Earth orbiting the nearby star GJ 1214 may look. Credit: [[ESO]]/L. Calçada]]
Discovered by the [[MEarth Project|MEarth project]] and investigated further by the HARPS spectrograph on [[European Southern Observatory|ESO]]’s 3.6-metre telescope at [[La Silla]], GJ 1214 b is the second super-Earth [[exoplanet]] for which astronomers have determined the mass and radius, giving vital clues about its structure. It is also the first super-Earth around which an atmosphere has been found. A search for additional planets using [[Methods of detecting extrasolar planets#Transit timing variation method (TTV) and transit duration variation method (TDV)|transit timing variations]] was negative.<ref name="Berta2011"/>
No transit-time variations have yet been found for this transit. As of 2012, "the given data does not allow us to conclude that there is a [second] planet in the mass range 0.1–5 Earth-masses and the period range 0.76–1.23 or 1.91–3.18 days."<ref name="Harpsøe"/> The X-ray flux from the host star is estimated to have stripped {{earth mass|2−5.6}} from the planet over the lifetime of the system.<ref name=Lalitha2014/>
==See also== * [[COROT-7]] * [[Gliese 581]] * [[Gliese 876]] * [[List of extrasolar planets]]

{{Infobox album | name = Concrete Jungle | type = studio | artist = [[Scorcher (rapper)|Scorcher]] | cover = | alt = | released = 23 November 2009 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Grime (music)|Grime]] | length = | label = | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} '''''Concrete Jungle''''' is a 2009 debut album by Scorcher released independently. The album is seen as a critical success in [[electronic music]], but a major disappointment to [[Grime (music)|grime]] fans. The albums has spawned two singles, 'I Know' and 'Lipsin' Ting', neither of which charted. The albums has been widely anticipated by many in the grime scene,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukrecordshop.com/item/scorcher-concrete-jungle.html |title=Scorcher - Concrete Jungle |publisher=Ukrecordshop.com |date=2009-11-23 |accessdate=2012-05-12}}</ref> but disappointed many in the scene. It features collaborations with the likes of Wiley, J2K, and Wretch 32. The album was inspired by a short freestyle by Scorcher.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rwdmag.com/music/grime-garage-bassline-and-dubstep/audio/scorcher-concrete-jungle |title=Music | RWD |publisher=Rwdmag.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-12}}</ref> The 3rd single from the album is 'Dark Knight'.
==Track listing== #"Dark Knight"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.play.com/Music/CD/-/8/33/-/12068620/Concrete-Jungle/Product.html?searchtype=genre |title=Scorcher - Concrete Jungle - CDs at Play.com (UK) |publisher=Play.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-12}}</ref> #"Space Invader" <small>(ft. Wizzy Wow)</small> #"Good Morning" <small> (ft. Wretch 32 and Kay Young) [Produced by Vex Music]</small> #"Standing On The Chairs" #"I Know" <small> (ft. Wiley and J2K)</small> #"London Boy" #"Trend Setters" <small>(ft. G-Frsh, Wretch 32 and Mercston)</small> #"Gangsta" #"Revenge" <small>(ft. The J.F.L.O.W.S)</small> #"We Don't Care" <small>(ft. Terminator)</small> #"Interlude" <small>(Performed by Grand Jones)</small> #"She Don't Know" <small>(ft. Darren B)</small> #"Turbulence" #"Grownard" #"Lights On" <small>(ft. Wretch 32 and Mercston)</small> #"This Is Me" #"Getaway" #"Pay-Per-View (Bonus)" #"Lipsin' Ting(Bonus)"
==Notes== <references/>

revision.text: {|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin | name=Hirth F-23 | image= | caption= }}{{Infobox Aircraft Engine |type=Twin cylinder [[two-stroke]] [[aircraft engine]] |manufacturer=[[Hirth]] |national origin=[[Germany]] |first run= |major applications= |produced= |number built= |program cost= |unit cost=[[United States dollar|US$]]4423 (base price 2009) |developed from= |variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Hirth F-23''' is a twin cylinder, [[horizontally-opposed]], [[two stroke]], [[carburetor|carburetted]] or optionally [[fuel injection|fuel injected]] aircraft engine designed for use on [[ultralight aircraft]].Cliche, Andre: ''Ultralight Aircraft Shopper's Guide'' 8th Edition, page G-3 Cybair Limited Publishing, 2001. {{ISBN|0-9680628-1-4}}{{cite web|url = http://www.recpower.com/F-23%202%20cycle%2050hp.htm|title = F-23 2 cycle 50hp |accessdate = 17 January 2013|last = Recreational Power Engineering |authorlink = |year = n.d.}}Purdy, Don: ''AeroCrafter - Homebuilt Aircraft Sourcebook'', page 72. BAI Communications. {{ISBN|0-9636409-4-1}} ==Development== The F-23 is intended to compete with the {{convert|50|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} [[Rotax 503]] and is differentiated from the [[Rotax]] powerplant by offering a horizontally-opposed cylinder layout. The F-23 uses free air cooling and piston-ported induction, with dual Bing 34mm slide or optional diaphragm type carburetors. The cylinder walls are electrochemically coated with [[Nikasil]]. Standard starting is [[recoil start]]. A belt reduction drive system, [[fuel injection]], tuned exhaust and electric start are optional. The engine runs on a 50:1 pre-mix of [[Avgas#Automotive gasoline|unleaded 93 octane auto fuel]] and oil. Recommended time between overhauls is 1000 hours. The F-23 produces {{convert|50|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 6150 rpm and {{convert|40|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 5500 rpm. ==Applications== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Aeronix Airelle]] *[[Air Sports AIRector 120]] *[[Aurore MB 02-2 Mini Bulle]] *[[DAR-23]] *[[Fisher FP-303]] *[[Monnett Moni]] - [[motorglider]] *[[Rotorschmiede VA115]] *[[Sadler Vampire]] *[[Solid Air Diamant LP]] *[[Spacek SD-1 Minisport]] *[[TechProAviation Merlin 100]] *[[Team Mini-Max AeroMax]] *[[TeST TST-1 Alpin]] *[[Wings of Freedom Phoenix 103]] }} ==Specifications (F-23) == {{pistonspecs| |ref=Recreational Power Engineering |type=Twin cylinder, two-stroke, aircraft engine |bore={{convert|72|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} |stroke={{convert|64|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} |displacement=521 cc (31.8 cu in) |length={{convert|247|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} |diameter= |width={{convert|570|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} |height={{convert|338|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} |weight={{convert|84|lb|kg|1|abbr=on}} including reduction unit, full exhaust system and electric start |valvetrain= piston-ported |supercharger= |turbocharger= |fuelsystem=2 X Bing 34mm slide or optional diaphragm type carburetor or fuel injection |fueltype=[[Avgas#Automotive gasoline|unleaded 93 octane auto fuel]] |oilsystem=50:1 fuel/oil premix |coolingsystem=free air |power={{convert|50|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 6150 rpm |specpower= |compression=9.5:1 |fuelcon= |specfuelcon= |oilcon= |power/weight= |designer= |reduction_gear= cog belt with 1.8:1, 2.2:1 and 2.5:1 ratios optional |general_other= |components_other= |performance_other= }} {{aircontent |see also= |related= |similar aircraft= |lists= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.recpower.com/F-23%202%20cycle%2050hp.htm}} {{Hirth aeroengines}} [[Category:Hirth aircraft engines]] [[Category:Air-cooled aircraft piston engines]] [[Category:Two-stroke aircraft piston engines]]

{{Infobox curler |name = Lisa Farnell |Curling club = [[Fenton's Curling Rink]],
[[Royal Tunbridge Wells]], [[England]] |Skip = '''Lisa Farnell''' |Third = [[Sara Jahovoda]] |Second = Victoria Kyle |Lead = Naimh Fenton |Alternate = |Hearts appearances = | European Championship appearances = 1 (2017) |birth_place=[[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada |birth_date={{bda|1986|9|23}} }} '''Lisa Farnell''' (born September 23, 1986 in [[Toronto]]) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]]-[[England|English]] [[curling|curler]] originally from [[Peterborough, Ontario]]. She was the skip of the Ontario team at the 2006 [[Canadian Junior Curling Championships]]. In 2006, Farnell and her team of [[Kim Brown (curler)|Kim Brown]], [[Darrelle Johnson]] and [[Amber Gebhardt]] won the provincial junior championships, earning the right to represent Ontario at the [[2006 Canadian Junior Curling Championships]] in [[Thunder Bay, Ontario]]. At the Canadian Juniors, the team finished with a 5-6 record, tied for sixth place. Farnell would later team up with 2005 provincial champion skip [[Erin Morrissey]] to form a competitive team on the women's [[World Curling Tour]]. The team made it to their first [[2010 Ontario Scotties Tournament of Hearts|provincial women's championship in 2010]], where they finished with a 5-4 record before losing in a tie-breaker match. Farnell won her first [[World Curling Tour]] event at the [[2013 Challenge Chateau Cartier de Gatineau]]. Her win involved defeating defending Canadian champion [[Rachel Homan]] in the semi-final and her third ([[Erin Morrissey]])'s sister, [[Katie Morrissey]] in the final. Farnell moved to [[London]],http://www.fentonsrink.co.uk/Offers-and-News [[England]] and will represent England at the [[2017 European Curling Championships]]. ==External links== *{{worldcurl|17010}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Farnell, Lisa}} [[Category:Curlers from Ontario]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Peterborough, Ontario]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Toronto]] [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:Sportspeople from London]] [[Category:Canadian women curlers]] [[Category:English female curlers]] [[Category:Canadian expatriates in England]] [[Category:Canadian expatriate sportspeople in the United Kingdom]]

'''Xunyang River''' ({{zh|c=浔阳江|p=Xúnyáng Jiāng}}) is a section of [[Yangtze River]] north of [[Jiujiang]], [[Jiangxi]] province, [[China]].
Jiujiang had ancient names like Chaisang ({{zh|c=柴桑|p=Chái Sāng}}) and Xunyang ({{zh|c=浔阳|p=Xúnyáng}}), thus the section of Yangtze River passing Jiujiang was thus named. Today, there is one [[Xunyang District]] in Jiujiang.
{{coord missing|Jiangxi}}

revision.text:
[[File:Siege of Leningrad, 1941-09-21.svg|thumb|300px|The front on 21 September 1941]] {{Campaignbox Leningrad and Baltics 1941–1944}} The '''Oranienbaum Bridgehead''' (Ораниенбаумский плацдарм in Russian) was an isolated portion of the [[Leningrad Oblast]] in Russia, which was retained under Soviet control during the [[siege of Leningrad]] in World War II. It played a significant role in protecting the city.
==History==
The area is located near the [[Lomonosov, Russia|town of Lomonosov]] (formerly Oranienbaum) and centred on the [[Krasnaya Gorka fort|Krasnaya Gorka Fort complex]]. The Germans approached Leningrad in early September 1941 and reached the Gulf of Finland on the 7th, isolating an area 65 km long and up to 25 km deep along the Baltic Coast. This area was heavily fortified and defended by the soldiers of the Red Army and Sailors of the Baltic Fleet. An attempt to link up with the main soviet forces around Leningrad, the Strelna Peterhof operation was mounted on 5–10 October but failed.
On 2 November 1941, the [[19th Rifle Corps]] was reorganised as the 2nd Neva Operations Group, then quickly the Coastal Operations Group, of the [[Leningrad Front]] to defend the pocket. It initially included the [[48th Rifle Division|48th]] and the 2nd and 5th Naval Rifle Brigades, under the former commander of the 19th Rifle Corps, General Antonov.
Later the garrison included the 48th Rifle Division, the [[98th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|98th]] and [[168th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|168th Rifle Divisions]] as well as parts of the [[Baltic Fleet]] which provided gunfire support and supply. The commander between 1942 and 1943 was General Vladimir Romanovsky. He was replaced by [[Ivan Fedyuninsky]] in December 1943. In November 1943, the [[2nd Shock Army]] was sent into the bridgehead. On 14 January 1944, the 2nd Shock Army attacked out of the bridgehead during the [[Krasnoye Selo–Ropsha Offensive]]. Part of the [[Leningrad–Novgorod Offensive]], it helped break the Siege of Leningrad.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Stalin's War with Germany: The road to Berlin|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6UaU6ZLqK4UC|publisher = Yale University Press|date = 1999-01-01|isbn = 0300078137|language = en|first = John|last = Erickson|pages = 167-171}}</ref>
==Monuments==
Several monuments from the [[Green Belt of Glory]] are located within the former bridgehead
==References== <references /> ''This article incorporates material from Russian Wikipedia'' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070510023152/http://www.encspb.ru/article.php?kod=2804035257 St Petersburg Encyclopedia (Russian)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120112021752/http://www.historus.ru/dwl/2.pdf - Russian Language Site] * [http://www.rkka.ru/oper/8army/8army5.htm Russian Language site rkka.ru]
{{coord missing|Russia}}

revision.text:
'''Marie Cornwall''' (born 1949) is the editor of the ''[[Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion]]'', a professor of [[sociology]] and women's studies at [[Brigham Young University]] (BYU) and a former director of BYU's Women's Research Institute.
==Biography== Cornwall holds a bachelor's degree in English from the [[University of Utah]], a master's degree in sociology from BYU and a [[Ph.D]]. in sociology from the [[University of Minnesota]].
===Career=== Besides being a member of the BYU faculty Cornwall was also a visiting professor at the [[University of Utah]] for one year.<ref>''Salt Lake Tribune'', Jan. 3, 2000{{full|date=December 2014}}</ref> She was a researcher for the [[Priesthood Correlation Program|LDS Church's Correlation Department]] prior to joining the BYU faculty, where she studied causes/patterns of Mormons leaving church activity for other ways of living.
Cornwall was one of the moving figures behind the growth of the [[Mormon Social Science Association]].<ref>[http://history.utah.gov/findAids/B01010/B1010.XML History of the Mormon Social Science Association ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130401204002/http://history.utah.gov/findaids/B01010/B1010.xml |date=2013-04-01 }}</ref>
==Publications== Among other subjects Cornwall has written articles on women's suffrage, unemployment, gender roles in housekeeping, plural marriage and religion and family in such journals as ''[[Mobilization]]''; ''[[Social Forces]]''; ''[[Journal of Marriage and the Family]]'' and ''[[Review of Religious Research]]''. Among other books, Cornwall edited ''Contemporary Mormonism: Social Science Perspectives'', with [[Tim B. Heaton]] and [[Lawrence A. Young]].<ref>{{citation |title= Contemporary Mormonism: Social Science Perspectives |editor1-first= Marie |editor1-last= Cornwall |editor2-first= Tim B. |editor2-last= Heaton |editor2-link= Tim B. Heaton |editor3-first= Lawrence A. |editor3-last= Young |year= 1994 |place= Urbana |publisher= University of Illinois Press |isbn= 0-252-06959-5 |oclc= 28721262 }}</ref> Along with [[Sherrie Mills Johnson]], Cornwall has done studies critical of the view that Mormon women are submissive and degraded.<ref>[http://www.fairlds.org/FAIR_Conferences/2004_Place_of_Mormon_Women.html article by Andrea Radke on Mormon women and mental health]</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091201140447/http://fhssfaculty.byu.edu/Faculty/mc27 BYU faculty bio of Cornwall] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100621152505/https://facultyprofile.byu.edu/PublicFacultyProfile/vita/vita_mc27.pdf Cornwall's vita] *[http://www.press.uillinois.edu/books/catalog/62hka9hf9780252069598.html University of Illinois Press blurb on Cornwall] *[http://search.barnesandnoble.com/BookSearch/results.asp?ATH=Marie+Cornwall Barnes and Noble listing of books by Cornwall] *[http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/123201903/abstract abstract of Cornwall's "From the Editor" piece in an issue of the ''Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion''] *[http://isbndb.com/d/person/cornwall_marie.html info on Cornwall] *[http://squaretwo.org/Sq2ArticleWRIFarewell.html "A Farewell Salute to the Women's Research Institute of Brigham Young University" in ''SquareTwo'', Vol. 2 No. 3 (Fall 2009)]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{hiero|Nesitanebetashru<ref>Hermann Ranke: ''Die ägyptische Persönennamen.'' Verlag von J. J. Augustin in Glückstadt, 1935.,p.179</ref>|<hiero>n:ns:z-Z4:Y1-t-A-nb:t-i-S:r-rw-n:n:n-Z92</hiero>|align=right|era=nk}} '''Nesitanebetashru''' ''(ns-t3-nb.t-ỉšrw)'' was the name of two [[ancient Egypt]]ian women. The name means “belonging to the lady of the ''ashru''”; the ''ashru'' or ''[[isheru]]'' was a crescent-shaped sacred lake around the temples of solar goddesses, here it refers to [[Mut]].
Nesitanebetashru of the [[Twenty-first dynasty of Egypt|21st dynasty]] was a daughter of [[Pinedjem II]], High Priest of Amun, and [[Neskhons]]. She is mentioned in the funerary text of her mother, written on a wooden tablet. Her mummy, coffins and [[ushabti]]s were found in the tomb [[TT320]] and are now in the [[Egyptian Museum]] in Cairo.<ref>{{dodson}}, p.208</ref>
Nesitanebetashru of the [[Twenty-second dynasty of Egypt|22nd dynasty]] was the wife of Pharaoh [[Sheshonk II]] and the mother of Pharaoh [[Harsiese A]]. She was also a Chantress of Amun. She is mentioned on a statue of [[Bes]].<ref>Dodson & Hilton; op.cit., p.221</ref>
==Sources== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://anubis4_2000.tripod.com/subpages1/NestanebetashruShrine.htm Mummy of Nesitanebetashru (21st dynasty)]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nesitanebetashru}} [[Category:10th-century BC women]] [[Category:9th-century BC women]] [[Category:Queens consort of the Twenty-first Dynasty of Egypt]] [[Category:Queens consort of the Twenty-second Dynasty of Egypt]] [[Category:Ancient Egyptian mummies]] [[Category:9th century BC in Egypt]]

The '''13th Toronto Film Critics Association Awards''', honoring the best in film for [[2009 in film|2009]], were given on December 16, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://torontofilmcritics.com/blog/2009/12/16/toronto-film-critics-association-awards-2009/|title=Toronto Film Critics Association Awards 2009|publisher=torontofilmcritics.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323084722/http://torontofilmcritics.com/blog/2009/12/16/toronto-film-critics-association-awards-2009|archivedate=2010-03-23|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://torontofilmcritics.com/blog/2010/01/06/toronto-film-critics-association-announces-winner-of-inaugural-jay-scott-prize-for-emerging-artist/|title=Toronto Film Critics Association Announces Winner Of Inaugural Jay Scott Prize For Emerging Artist|publisher=torontofilmcritics.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006005803/http://torontofilmcritics.com/blog/2010/01/06/toronto-film-critics-association-announces-winner-of-inaugural-jay-scott-prize-for-emerging-artist/|archivedate=2011-10-06|df=}}{{cite Award|publisher=torontofilmcritics.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006005943/http://torontofilmcritics.com/blog/2010/01/12/polytechnique-wins-the-2009-rogers-best-canadian-film-award/|archivedate=2011-10-06|df=}} ==Winners== *'''Best Actor:''' **[[Nicolas Cage]] – ''[[Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans]]'' Runners-Up: [[George Clooney]] – ''[[Up in the Air (2009 film)|Up in the Air]]'', [[Michael Fassbender]] – ''[[Hunger (2008 film)|Hunger]]'', [[Colin Firth]] – ''[[A Single Man]]'' and [[Viggo Mortensen]] – ''[[The Road (2009 film)|The Road]]'' *'''Best Actress:''' **[[Carey Mulligan]] – ''[[An Education]]'' Runners-Up: [[Arta Dobroshi]] – ''[[Lorna's Silence]]'' and [[Meryl Streep]] – ''[[Julie & Julia]]'' *'''Best Animated Film:''' **''[[Fantastic Mr. Fox (film)|Fantastic Mr. Fox]]'' Runners-Up: ''[[Coraline (film)|Coraline]]'' and ''[[Up (2009 film)|Up]]'' *'''Best Director:''' **[[Kathryn Bigelow]] – ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'' Runners-Up: [[Steve McQueen]] – ''[[Hunger (2008 film)|Hunger]]'' and [[Quentin Tarantino]] – ''[[Inglourious Basterds]]'' *'''Best Documentary Film:''' **''[[The Cove (film)|The Cove]]'' Runners-Up: ''[[Anvil! The Story of Anvil]]'' and ''[[The Beaches of Agnès]]'' *'''Best Film (tie):''' **'''''[[Hunger (2008 film)|Hunger]]'' **'''''[[Inglourious Basterds]]'' Runner-Up: ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'' *'''Best First Feature:''' **''[[Hunger (2008 film)|Hunger]]'' Runners-Up: ''[[District 9]]'' and ''[[500 Days of Summer|(500) Days of Summer]]'' *'''Best Foreign Language Film:''' **''[[The White Ribbon]]'' • [[Austria]] Runner-Up: ''[[Police, Adjective]]'' • [[Romania]] and ''[[Summer Hours]]'' • [[France]] *'''Best Screenplay (tie):''' **''[[Inglourious Basterds]]'' – [[Quentin Tarantino]] **''[[Up in the Air (2009 film)|Up in the Air]]'' – [[Jason Reitman]] and [[Sheldon Turner]] Runner-Up: ''[[A Serious Man]]'' – [[Joel and Ethan Coen]] *'''Best Supporting Actor:''' **[[Christoph Waltz]] – ''[[Inglourious Basterds]]'' Runners-Up: [[Christian McKay]] – ''[[Me and Orson Welles]]'' and [[Timothy Olyphant]] – ''[[A Perfect Getaway]]'' *'''Best Supporting Actress:''' **[[Anna Kendrick]] – ''[[Up in the Air (2009 film)|Up in the Air]]'' Runners-Up: [[Vera Farmiga]] – ''[[Up in the Air (2009 film)|Up in the Air]]'' and [[Mo'Nique]] – ''[[Precious (film)|Precious]]'' *'''Jay Scott Prize for Emerging Talent:''' **[[Xavier Dolan]] *'''Rogers Canadian Film Award:''' **''[[Polytechnique (film)|Polytechnique]]'' Runners-Up: ''[[The Necessities of Life]]'' and ''[[Pontypool (film)|Pontypool]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} {{TFCA Awards Chron}} [[Category:Toronto Film Critics Association Awards|2008]] [[Category:2009 film awards]] [[Category:2009 in Canadian cinema|Tor]] [[Category:2009 in Ontario]]

revision.comment: Wrong year. It was not published in 2018. Got rid of the "The Lifetime" bit in the upper right corner. The poem is by Arnold. It was published in 1853 and I'm not sure why the author was listed as "YashSingh." I still need to find the publisher.
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox short story | name = The Scholar-Gipsy | image = | caption = | title_orig = | translator = | author = Matthew Arnold | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = [[Elegy]], [[Topographical poetry|topographical poem]] | published_in = ''Poems'' | publication_type = | publisher = | media_type = Print (hardback) | pub_date = 1853 | english_pub_date = | preceded_by = | followed_by = [[Thyrsis (poem)|Thyrsis]] }} "'''The Scholar Gipsy'''" (1853) is a poem by [[Matthew Arnold]], based on a 17th-century [[Oxford]] story found in [[Joseph Glanvill]]'s ''The Vanity of Dogmatizing'' (1661, etc.). It has often been called one of the best and most popular of Arnold's poems,R. C. Churchill ''English Literature of the Nineteenth Century'' (London: University Tutorial Press, 1951) p. 140; Mary Moorman ''Poets and Historians: A Family Inheritance'' (Lincoln: Tennyson Society, 1974) p. 11; A. G. George ''Studies in Poetry'' (London: Heinemann Educational, 1971) p. 262. and is also familiar to music-lovers through [[Ralph Vaughan Williams]]' choral work ''[[An Oxford Elegy]]'', which sets lines from this poem and from its companion-piece, "[[Thyrsis (poem)|Thyrsis]]".[[Michael Kennedy (music critic)|Michael Kennedy]] ''The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Music'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1980) p. 472. == The original story == Arnold prefaces the poem with an extract from [[Joseph Glanvill|Glanvill]] which tells the story of an impoverished Oxford student who left his studies to join a band of [[Romani people|gipsies]], and so ingratiated himself with them that they told him many of the secrets of their trade. After some time he was discovered and recognised by two of his former Oxford associates, who learned from him that the gipsies "had a traditional kind of learning among them, and could do wonders by the power of imagination, their fancy binding that of others." When he had learned everything that the gipsies could teach him, he said, he would leave them and give an account of these secrets to the world. In 1929 [[Marjorie Hope Nicolson]] identified the original of this mysterious figure as the Flemish alchemist [[Franciscus Mercurius van Helmont|Francis Mercury van Helmont]].The Real Scholar Gipsy by Marjorie Nicolson in ''Yale Review'' vol. 18 (1929) pp. 347–363. == Synopsis == Arnold begins "The Scholar Gipsy" in [[pastoral]] mode, invoking a shepherd and describing the beauties of a rural scene, with Oxford in the distance. He then repeats the gist of Glanvill's story, but extends it with an account of rumours that the scholar gipsy was again seen from time to time around Oxford. Arnold imagines him as a shadowy figure who can even now be glimpsed in the Berkshire and Oxfordshire countryside, "waiting for the spark from Heaven to fall",Line 120 and claims to have once seen him himself. He entertains a doubt as to the scholar gypsy's still being alive after two centuries, but then shakes off the thought. He cannot have died:
For what wears out the life of mortal men?
'Tis that from change to change their being rolls:
'Tis that repeated shocks, again, again,
Exhaust the energy of strongest souls,
And numb the elastic powers.Line 142.
The scholar gipsy, having renounced such a life, is
Free from the sick fatigue, the languid doubt,
Which much to have tried, in much been baffled, brings,Line 164.
and is therefore not subject to ageing and death. Arnold describes
this strange disease of modern life,
With its sick hurry, its divided aims,Line 203.
and implores the scholar gipsy to avoid all who suffer from it, in case he too should be infected and die. Arnold ends with an extended simile of a Tyrian merchant seaman who flees from the irruption of Greek competitors to seek a new world in Iberia. == Writing and publication == "The Scholar Gipsy" was written in 1853, probably immediately after "[[Sohrab and Rustum]]".[[Kenneth Allott]] and Miriam Allott (eds.) ''The Poems of Matthew Arnold'' (London: Longman, 1979) p. 355. In an 1857 letter to his brother [[Tom Arnold (academic)|Tom]], referring to their friendship with Theodore Walrond and the poet [[Arthur Hugh Clough]], Arnold wrote that "The Scholar Gipsy" was "meant to fix the remembrance of those delightful wanderings of ours in the [[Cumnor|Cumner]] hills before they were quite effaced".Deborah Epstein Nord ''Gypsies and the British Imagination, 1807–1930'' (New York: Columbia University Press, 2006) pp. 60–61. Arnold revisited these scenes many years later in his elegy for Arthur Hugh Clough, "[[Thyrsis (poem)|Thyrsis]]", a companion-piece and, some would say,For example [[George Saintsbury]] in ''Matthew Arnold'' (Teddington: Echo Library, 2006) p. 20. a sequel to "The Scholar Gipsy". "The Scholar Gipsy", like "Requiescat" and "[[Sohrab and Rustum]]", first appeared in Arnold's ''Poems'' (1853), published by [[Longman]]s. During the 20th century it was many times published as a booklet, either by itself or with "Thyrsis".[http://copac.ac.uk/search?au=matthew+arnold&ti=scholar+gipsy&sort-order=date Catalogue entry] at [[Copac]]. It appears in ''[[Oxford Book of English Verse|The Oxford Book of English Verse]]'' and in some editions of [[Francis Turner Palgrave|Palgrave]]'s ''[[Palgrave's Golden Treasury|Golden Treasury]]'' despite its being, at 250 lines, considerably longer than most of the poems in either anthology. == Critical opinions ==
Homer ''animates'' – Shakespeare ''animates'', in its poor way I think [[Sohrab and Rustum]] ''animates'' – the "Gipsy Scholar" at best awakens a pleasing melancholy. But this is not what we want.
                                          The complaining millions of men
                                          Darken in labour and pain –
what they want is something to ''animate'' and ''ennoble'' them – not merely to add zest to their melancholy or grace to their dreams.
                                          Matthew ArnoldLetter to [[Arthur Hugh Clough]], November 1853, cited from Carl Dawson (ed.) ''Matthew Arnold: The Critical Heritage'' (London: Routledge, 1995) vol. 2, p. 123.
We would ask Mr. Arnold to consider whether the acceptance this poem is sure to win, does not prove to him that it is better to forget all his poetic theories, ay, and [[Homer]] and [[Sophocles]], [[John Milton|Milton]] and [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]] too, and speak straight out of things which he has felt and tested on his own pulses.
                                          ''The North British Review''Unsigned review, possibly by [[Coventry Patmore]] or [[John Campbell Shairp|J. C. Shairp]], from ''[[The North British Review]]'', August 1854, cited from Carl Dawson (ed.) ''Matthew Arnold: The Critical Heritage'' (London: Routledge, 1995) vol. 2, p. 113.
"The Scholar Gipsy" has sunk into the common consciousness; it is inseparable from Oxford; it is the poetry of Oxford made, in some sense, complete.
                                          [[John William Mackail]][[John William Mackail|J. W. Mackail]] ''Lectures on Poetry'' (London: Longmans, 1911) p. 242.
"The Scholar Gipsy" represents very closely the ghost of each one of us, the living ghost, made up of many recollections and some wishes and promises; the excellence of the study is in part due to the poet's refusal to tie his wanderer to any actual gipsy camp or any invention resembling a plot.
                                          [[Edmund Blunden]]Matthew Arnold ''The Scholar-Gipsy'' (London: Nicholson & Watson, 1933) pp. 6–8.
What the poem actually offers is a charm of relaxation, a holiday from serious aims and exacting business. And what the Scholar-Gipsy really symbolises is Victorian poetry, vehicle (so often) of explicit intellectual and moral intentions, but unable to be in essence anything but relaxed, relaxing and anodyne.
                                          [[F. R. Leavis]][[F. R. Leavis]] ''The Common Pursuit'', cited from [[Harold Bloom]] (ed.) ''The Art of the Critic: Literary Theory and Criticism from the Greeks to the Present'' (New York: Chelsea House, 1985–1990) vol. 9, p. 100.
== Notes == {{reflist}} == External links == {{wikisource|The Scholar-Gipsy}} * [http://www.victorianweb.org/authors/arnold/sullivan2.html "Matthew Arnold, 'The Scholar Gipsy,' and the Cumnor Hills" – a topographical essay by Dick Sullivan] * [http://yabaluri.org/TRIVENI/CDWEB/thescholargipsyofmatthewarnoldapr74.htm Critical study by R. A. Jayantha] * [http://www.exclassics.com/glanvil/glan29.htm#scholar Glanvil's story of The Scholar Gipsy] {{Matthew Arnold}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scholar Gipsy, The}} [[Category:Poetry by Matthew Arnold]] [[Category:1853 poems]] [[Category:Vale of White Horse]] [[Category:Culture in Oxford]] [[Category:Fictional representations of Romani people]]

revision.text:
'''Margret Antonie Boveri''' (14 August 1900 – 6 July 1975){{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=01dvizg_hCoC&pg=PA560&dq=margret+boveri+august+1900&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_k4T2woTXAhUo_IMKHYaECRUQ6AEIRDAE#v=onepage&q=margret%20boveri%20august%201900&f=false|title=Exil im Nebelland: Elisabeth Castoniers Briefe an Mary Tucholsky : eine Chronik|last=Castonier|first=Elisabeth|date=2010|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=9783039100378|language=de}} was one of the best-known [[Germany|German]] journalists and writers of the post-[[World War II]] period. ==Life== Margret Boveri was born in [[Würzburg]], [[German Empire|Germany]], the daughter of German biologist [[Theodor Boveri]] and American biologist [[Marcella Boveri|Marcella O'Grady Boveri]]. Her father died in 1915 and her mother returned to the USA in 1925. She studied history and political science in Munich and Berlin. From 1934 she worked in the Foreign Affairs section of the ''[[Berliner Tageblatt]]'' newspaper, where she was promoted by the editor, [[Paul Scheffer]].Heike B. Görtemaker: ''Ein deutsches Leben. Die Geschichte der Margret Boveri, München'', 2005 From 1939 until 1943 (when the newspaper was banned) she worked as foreign correspondent for the ''[[Frankfurter Zeitung]]'' newspaper in [[Stockholm]] and [[New York City]]. She was awarded the [[War Merit Medal]] by the [[Nazi]] Government in 1941; she herself was never a member of the Nationalist Socialist Party. After the USA entered the war she was interned for a time in New York, before being returned, at her own request, to Europe. In May 1942 she arrived in [[Lisbon]], where she continued her work as correspondent for the ''Frankfurter Zeitung''. While in Lisbon she became acquainted with the Swiss journalist [[Annemarie Schwarzenbach]], who was to die shortly afterwards in an accident in Switzerland.Gillessen, Günther: ''Auf verlorenem Posten. Die Frankfurter Zeitung im Dritten Reich''. Berlin 1986, p. 479 et passim. After the ''[[Frankfurter Zeitung]]'' was banned by the German government in 1943, Boveri returned to Berlin, where her apartment was destroyed in an air strike. She then took up work as a report writer in the German embassy in [[Madrid]] before returning to Berlin in 1944 to work as a freelance writer with the National Socialist weekly ''[[Das Reich (newspaper)|Das Reich]]''. [[File:Gedenktafel Opitzstr 8 Margret Boveri.JPG|thumb|Memorial at Opitzstraße 8 in [[Berlin-Steglitz]]]] After the war Boveri disapproved of the division of Germany by the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] into separate political zones, in which she was supported by [[Konrad Adenauer]], and she maintained her opposition to the division of Germany until the 1960s. In 1968 she was awarded the [[German Critics' Prize]] and in 1970 the [[Bundesverdienstkreuz]], the highest civilian honour in [[West Germany]], for promoting understanding between East and West Germany.Heike B. Görtemaker: ''Ein deutsches Leben. Die Geschichte der Margret Boveri, München'', 2005, S. 313 Among her friends and acquaintances were [[Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen]], [[Theodor Heuss]], [[Ernst von Weizsäcker]], [[Freya von Moltke]], [[Ernst Jünger]], [[Carl Schmitt]], [[Armin Mohler]], [[Gottfried Benn]] und [[Uwe Johnson]]. She died in Berlin in 1975. ==Works== * ''Das Weltgeschehen am Mittelmeer'', Zurich 1936 * ''Vom Minarett zum Bohrturm. Eine politische Biographie Vorderasiens'', Zurich and Leipzig 1939 * ''Ein Auto, Wüsten, blaue Perlen. Bericht über eine Reise durch Vorderasien'', Leipzig 1939 * modern edition: ''Wüsten, Minarette und Moscheen. Im Auto durch den alten Orient.'' Berlin, wjs 2005, {{ISBN|3-937989-06-4}} * ''Amerika-Fibel für erwachsene Deutsche'', Berlin 1946 (modern edition: Berlin (Landt) 2006, {{ISBN|3-938844-03-5}} * ''16 Fenster und 8 Türen'', Berlin 1953 * ''Der Verrat im XX. Jahrhundert'', 4 Volumes, Hamburg 1956–1960 * ''Wir lügen alle. Eine Hauptstadtzeitung unter Hitler'', Olten and Freiburg im Breisgau 1965 * ''Tage des Überlebens. Berlin 1945'', Munich 1968. Modern edition: Berlin, wjs 2004, {{ISBN|3-937989-01-3}} * ''Erinnerte Mutmaßungen'', in: ''Neue Deutsche Hefte'' 16, 205–208, 1969 * ''Die Deutschen und der Status Quo'', Munich 1974 * ''Verzweigungen. Eine Autobiographie'', published by [[Uwe Johnson]], Munich 1977
modern edition: Frankfurt am Main, Suhrkamp 1996, {{ISBN|3-518-39076-7}} ==References== * {{Citation | title = Theodor Boveri: The Life of a Great Biologist 1862-1915 | first = Fritz | last = Baltzer | year = 1967 | url = http://www.devbio.com/article.php?ch=7&id=75 | accessdate = 2007-07-22 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050228170412/http://www.devbio.com/article.php?ch=7&id=75 | archivedate = 2005-02-28 | df = }}. Extract published in {{Citation | last = Gilbert | first = SF | title = DevBio: a companion to Developmental Biology, 8th ed | year = 2006 | publisher = Sinauer Associates }} * Belke, Ingrid: ''Auswandern oder bleiben? Die Publizistin Margret Boveri (1900–1975) im Dritten Reich.'' In: ''Zeitschrift für Geschichtswissenschaft'' 53 (2005), S. 118–137. * Görtemaker, Heike B.: ''Ein deutsches Leben. Die Geschichte der Margret Boveri'', Munich, C.H. Beck 2005, {{ISBN|3-406-52873-2}} * Dambitsch, David: ''Eine Dame von Welt - Die politische Journalistin Margret Boveri (1900–1975)'', Munich, {{ISBN|3-935168-43-8}} * Gillessen, Günther: ''Auf verlorenem Posten. Die Frankfurter Zeitung im Dritten Reich.'' Berlin 1986 * [[Ernst Klee]]: ''„Margret Boveri“'' Eintrag in ders.: ''Das Kulturlexikon zum Dritten Reich. Wer war was vor und nach 1945''. S. Fischer, Frankfurt am Main 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-10-039326-5}} ==External links== * {{DNB portal|118514067|TYP=}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boveri, Margret}} [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1975 deaths]] [[Category:German journalists]] [[Category:German people of American descent]] [[Category:German people of Irish descent]] [[Category:German women writers]] [[Category:People from Würzburg]] [[Category:Officers Crosses of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]] [[Category:20th-century women writers]] [[Category:20th-century German writers]]

revision.text:
'''Kulla''', inscribed in [[cuneiform]] as <sup>d</sup><small>SIG</small><sub>4</sub>, where <small>SIG</small><sub>4</sub> was the [[Sumerogram]] for [[Akkadian language|Akkadian]] word ''libittu'', “brick,”<ref>''libittu'', CAD L p. 176.</ref> was the [[Sumer]]o-[[Babylonia]]n brick-god who was invoked alongside [[Mushdamma|Mušdam]], the divine architect at the outset when laying a foundation for a building, but consequently banished when construction work was completed in elaborate incantation rituals which formed a part of the exorcists curriculum. He was formed from a piece of clay that [[Enki|Ea]] had pinched off in the primeval ocean, in a tale recited as part of the ritual for restoring a temple, “when [[Anu]] created heaven.”
==The rituals==
The earliest attestations to the god whose specialty was to govern the fashioning of bricks and supervise the building process from start to finish was in the [[Sumerian language|Sumerian]] myth 'Enki and the World Order' from the first dynasty of [[Isin]] which recalls that Enki put Kulla in charge of the pickaxe and brick-mold.<ref>{{ cite book | title = Foundation Deposits in Ancient Mesopotamia | author = Richard S. Ellis | publisher = Yale Press | year = 1968 | page = 18 }}</ref> He was invoked when the laying of the foundation of buildings, and shooed-away upon their completion, lest his presence cause further construction to be required and other building work elsewhere to be neglected. In a ritual for the repair of a temple, the invocation is described:
{{ quotation|[I]f one has to open the foundations of a house, in a propitious month, on a favourable day, when he opens the foundations and lays the brick … you set up an offering arrangement to Kulla, the lord of foundations and brickwork, set out a censor of juniper, libate fine beer, scatter pressed-out sesame, cedar resin, cypress oil, honey, milk, wine, all kinds of stone, silver, gold and all kinds of aromatics into the River god, sacrifice a ram and pour its blood into the foundations.<ref name=parpola>{{ cite book | title = Letters from Assyrian Scholars to the Kings Esarhaddon and Assurbanipal Part II: Commentary and Appendices | author = Simo Parpola | publisher = Eisenbrauns | year = 2007 | pages = 279–280 }}</ref> }}
In [[Esarhaddon]]’s account of the laying of the foundations of [[Esagil]], he recalls:
{{ quotation|I performed pure sacrifices to the great gods and Kulla, the lord of the fundament and the brickwork, I laid their foundations [upon a … mixed with] wind and choice beer, and made their superstructure durable.<ref name=parpola/> }}
A second ritual was often performed at the end of the work to drive away the god, with him unceremoniously “loaded” onto a boat and banished to the netherworld with incantations. The construction crew, too, were forbidden to approach the building for three days. Alternatively the divinities were thanked for their assistance and bidden to return from whence they came.
==External links==
* Laying the foundations of a house text at [http://www.etana.org/node/574 eTACT] * Exorcising Kulla (the brick god) from a newly built house text at [http://www.etana.org/node/573 eTACT]
==References==
{{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kulla (god)}} [[Category:Mesopotamian gods]]

They have a [[radula]] which bears a rachidian tooth whose upper margin is either smooth or notched; the lateral tooth has two crowns, and the other teeth are so flat as to resemble plates.{{Cite journal | last1 = Pola | first1 = M. | last2 = Cervera | first2 = J. revision.text:
{{Third Camp}}
'''Albert Glotzer''' (1908–1999), also known as '''Albert Gates''' was a professional [[stenographer]] and founder of the [[Trotskyist]] movement in the United States. He was best remembered as the court reporter for the 1937 [[John Dewey Commission]] that examined the Stalinist charges against Trotsky in Mexico City and as a memoirist and activist in the [[social democratic]] movement in his later years.
== Biography ==
=== Early years ===
Albert Glotzer was born November 7, 1908, to a [[Jewish people|Jewish]] family in [[Pinsk]], Belorussia (modern-day [[Belarus]]), then part of the [[Russian Empire]]. Glotzer and his family emigrated to [[Chicago]] when he was four.
=== Political career ===
Politically active since childhood, he was selling [[socialist]] literature on the street corners by age eight, and joined the [[Young Communist League]] at fifteen.<ref name=Wohlforth>Tim Wohlforth, [http://www.revolutionaryhistory.co.uk/obituaries/obituaries/albert.htm "Albert Glotzer (1908-1999): Obituary,"] Revolutionary History, www.revolutionaryhistory.co.uk/</ref> By the end of the 1920s Glotzer was elected a member of the National Executive Committee of the [[Young Workers League of America|Young Workers (Communist) League]].<ref name=JoinOp>[http://www.marxists.org/history/etol/newspape/themilitant/1928/01dec1928.pdf "Swabeck and Glotzer Join Opposition; Expelled,"] ''The Militant,'' vol. 1, no. 2 (Dec. 1, 1928), pg. 1.</ref>
In the fall of 1928 Glotzer and his Chicago co-thinker [[Arne Swabeck]] expelled from the [[Communist Party USA|Workers (Communist) Party]] and its youth section for espousing [[Trotskyism]].<ref name=Myers32>Constance Ashton Myers, ''The Prophet's Army: Trotskyists in America, 1928-1941.'' Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1977; pg. 32.</ref> News of the ouster of Glotzer and Swabeck was front-page news in the second issue of ''[[The Militant]],'' the first American Trotskyist newspaper.<ref name=JoinOp />
Glotzer was a delegate to the founding convention of the [[Communist League of America (Opposition)]] (CLA) in May 1929 and was elected as one of five members of the governing National Council of the fledgling organization.<ref>Myers, ''The Prophet's Army,'' pg. 53.</ref> At that time Glotzer moved to [[New York City]] to work at the new organization's national office.<ref name=Wohlforth />
Glotzer was involved in the factional difficulties that best the CLA from the very beginning. He originally gravitated toward [[James P. Cannon]] and Arne Swabeck, with whom he had worked in Chicago, but soon became a close ally of [[Max Shachtman]], who felt that Cannon was running the party in a bureaucratic and manner.
In 1931, Glotzer traveled with his wife to visit Leon Trotsky at [[Prinkipo]], Turkey, where he spent some weeks as a secretary and guard to the exiled Soviet leader.<ref name=Wohlforth /> According to Glotzer's wife they subsisted on the fish they caught in the [[Sea of Marmara]].<ref name="Albert Glotzer obituary">''Jewish Daily Forward'' [http://web.comhem.se/~u18606447/genealogy/texts/obit_ag.html Albert Glotzer obituary] March 12, 1999</ref> Trotsky advised a truce between the two factions, and Glotzer returned to the US to go on a national speaking tour on the dangers of [[fascism]].
By June 1932 Glotzer's criticism of Cannon became explicit. Together with [[Martin Abern]] and Max Shachtman, Glotzer made charges that Cannon had showed signs of an "ingrowing conservatism" after 1928, taking long absences from party duty over "personal difficulties" and leaving operations in the hands of a tightly-knit group of close personal supporters who controlled criticism in the party press.<ref name=Myers150>Myers, ''The Prophet's Army,'' pg. 150.</ref> Abern, Glotzer, and Shachtman declared that "new forces" were needed to revitalize the flagging CLA.<ref name=Myers150 /> Relations between the top leaders were patched up at this juncture and no split of the organization ensued.
When the unity negotiations with [[A. J. Muste|A.J. Muste's]] [[American Workers Party]] began in 1934, Cannon and Shactman became factional allies. Glotzer felt alienated from the policy, however. He returned to Chicago but stayed loyal to the Trotskyist movement.<ref name=Wohlforth />
In April 1937 the skilled [[stenographer]] Glotzer was sent to [[Mexico City]] to serve as [[court reporter]] at the [[Dewey Commission|John Dewey Commission]] called to hear charges made by the [[Joseph Stalin]] regime against Leon Trotsky. This commission heard evidence for a week before rendering a verdict clearing Trotsky of charges of espionage and sabotage levied against him in the ongoing [[Moscow Trials]]. The transcript produced by Glotzer was later published in book form by the American Trotskyist movement.
In the United States the Trotskyists emerged from the Socialist party as the [[Socialist Workers Party (United States)|Socialist Workers Party]]. After the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact|Nazi-Soviet Pact]] and the beginning of the [[World War II|Second World War]], Shachtman, Abern, and others condemned the USSR's alliance with Nazi Germany and their cooperative invasion of Poland. Schachtman condemned the USSR's invasion of Finland. Viewing these invasions, Shachtman argued that the USSR was not a "workers' state", but a new form of class-stratified society, "[[bureaucratic collectivism]]", in which workers and peasants were exploited by a class of bureaucratic elites.<ref>S. Ryan [http://www.marxists.org/history/etol/entries/glotz01.htm "Albert Glotzer,"] Encyclopedia of Trotskyism Online, Marxists Internet Archive, www.marxists.org/</ref>
Glotzer joined with Shachtman and helped to found the [[Workers Party (U.S.)|Workers Party]], later known as the [[Independent Socialist League]], which was absorbed by the Socialist Party in 1958. In 1972, the Socialist Party voted to rename itself [[Social Democrats, USA]] (SDUSA). Glotzer served on the SDUSA's National Committee for the rest of his life.<ref name=Reed>Dale Reed, [http://cdn.calisphere.org/data/13030/9d/tf1t1n989d/files/tf1t1n989d.pdf "Register of the Albert Glotzer papers,"] Hoover Institution Archives, Stanford University, Palo Alto, CA, 2010.</ref>
=== Death and legacy ===
Albert Glotzer died February 18, 1999. He was 90 years old at the time of his death.
Albert Glotzer's papers are housed in 67 archival boxes at the [[Hoover Institution Archives]] at [[Stanford University]] in [[Palo Alto, California]]. An on-line finding guide is available.<ref name=Reed />
Besides remaining a speaker Glotzer was active in the stenographers union, [[Federation of Shorthand Reporters]], [[AFL-CIO]]. He served four terms as union president during the 1960s.<ref name="Albert Glotzer obituary"/>
== Footnotes == {{Reflist|2}}
== Works == *[http://www.marxists.org/archive/trotsky/1937/dewey/ ''The Case of Leon Trotsky: Report of Hearings on the Charges Made Against Him in the Moscow Trials.''] New York: [[Harper (publisher)|Harper]], 1937.(stenographer) * [https://archive.org/details/IncentivePayTheSpeed-upNewStyle ''Incentive Pay: The Speed-up New Style.''] New York: Workers Party, 1945 (as Albert Gates). * "Introduction" (as Albert Gates) to Leon Trotsky [https://archive.org/details/MarxismInTheUnitedStates ''Marxism in the United States.''] New York: Workers Party, 1947. *''Trotsky: Memoir and Critique.'' Buffalo, NY: [[Prometheus Books]], 1989.
== External links == *[http://www.marxists.org/history/etol/writers/glotzer/index.htm Albert Glotzer Internet Archive], Marxists Internet Archive, www.marxists.org/ * Dale Reed, [http://cdn.calisphere.org/data/13030/9d/tf1t1n989d/files/tf1t1n989d.pdf "Register of the Albert Glotzer papers,"] Hoover Institution Archives, Stanford University, Palo Alto, CA, 2010.

Katz | editing = Bill Butler | studio = | distributor = [[American International Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1978|05| |U.S.}} | runtime = 92 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Our Winning Season''''' is a 1978 American [[drama (film and television)|drama film]] directed by [[Joseph Ruben]] from a screenplay by Nicholas Niciphor. ==Plot== During the 1960s, David Wakefield is a distance runner for his high school's track and field team who hopes to compete in college. His sister Cathy's boyfriend, Dean Berger, is a former track star who tries to advise David, telling him to be more patient during races and hold back, rather than exhausting himself by going too fast too soon. David is influenced by others in school, like friend Paul Morelli, and reassesses his life after Dean goes off to the [[Vietnam War]] and is killed. ==Cast== *[[Scott Jacoby (actor)|Scott Jacoby]] as David Wakefield *Deborah Benson as Alice Baker *[[Dennis Quaid]] as Paul Morelli *Robert Wahler as Burton Fleishauer *Randy Hermann as Jerry McDuffy (as Randy Herman) *[[Joe Penny]] as Dean Berger *[[Jan Smithers]] as Cathy Wakefield *[[P.J. Soles]] as Cindy Hawkins *Wendy Rastattar as Susie Wilson (as Wendy Rastatter) *Damon Douglas as Miller (as Damom Douglas) *[[Joanna Cassidy]] as Sheila *[[J. Don Ferguson]] as Coach Michael Murphy *Jeff Soracco as Eddie Rice *Ted Henning as Mr. Wetzle == External links == * {{IMDb title|0078047}} * {{amg movie|105174}} {{Joseph Ruben}} [[Category:1978 films]] [[Category:American coming-of-age films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American International Pictures films]] [[Category:Films set in the 1960s]] [[Category:Films shot in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Films directed by Joseph Ruben]] [[Category:1970s drama films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:Films produced by Joe Roth]] [[Category:Running films]] {{1970s-drama-film-stub}}

{{Infobox video game |title = Bush vs. Kerry Boxing |image = Bush vs Kerry title.jpg |developer = [[Glu Mobile|Sorrent]] |publisher = [[Glu Mobile|Sorrent]] |designer = |engine = |released = {{vgrelease|NA|August 22, 2004}} |genre = [[Boxing]] |modes = [[Single player]] |platforms = [[Mobile game|Moible]] }}
'''''Bush vs. Kerry Boxing''''' is a [[boxing]] [[video game]] developed and published by [[Glu Mobile|Sorrent]] for [[Mobile game|mobile phones]]. It was released in North America on August 22, 2004.
The game allows the player to choose to play as either [[George W. Bush]] or [[John Kerry]] to fight out the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 United States presidential election]]; the candidate chosen must fight through a number of preliminary rounds against the opponent's supporters in order to eventually fight the opposing candidate. ''Bush vs. Kerry Boxing'' garnered mostly positive reviews from critics. As of 2009, ''Bush vs. Kerry Boxing'' has received a 75.5% from [[GameRankings]].<ref name="gr">{{cite web|title=Bush vs. Kerry Boxing for Mobile|publisher=[[GameRankings]] |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/mobile/922005-bush-vs-kerry-boxing/index.html|accessdate=December 16, 2009}}</ref>
==Gameplay== [[File:Bush vs Kerry Boxing screen.jpg|thumb|left|The player fights [[Dick Cheney]].]] ''Bush vs. Kerry Boxing'' is for the most part a re-purposing of another [[Sorrent]] boxing title, ''[[Fox Sports Boxing]]'', with election characters instead of more standard pugilists.<ref name="GS" /> The game is a [[first person (video games)|first person]] [[boxing]] game; the game is seen from behind the player's gloves.<ref name="IGN">{{cite web|title=Bush vs. Kerry Boxing|author=Buchanan, Levi|date=August 30, 2004|publisher=[[IGN]] |url=http://wireless.ign.com/articles/543/543284p1.html|accessdate=December 16, 2009}}</ref> The game's view is filled by the opponent, as they dodge, punch, and counter against the player. Both the player and the opponent have a stamina meter, which as they perform actions is slowly drained.<ref name="IGN" /> The character is [[Knockout|KO'd]] after the stamina meter runs out unless the player can press the 0 button on the phone enough times to make a recovery.<ref name="GS">{{cite web|title=Bush vs. Kerry Boxing Review|author=Palley, Steve|date=August 25, 2004|publisher=[[GameSpot]] |url=http://www.gamespot.com/mobile/sports/bushvskerryboxing/review.html|accessdate=December 16, 2009}}</ref>
''Bush vs. Kerry Boxing'' features many prominent politicians from around the time of the 2004 Presidential election. The game gives the player the choice between playing as [[George W. Bush]] or [[John Kerry]], the two main candidates from the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 United States presidential election]].<ref name="IGN" /> The opponents the player faces change depending on which candidate he chooses to fight with; if the player chooses Bush, the player faces [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] opponents such as [[John Edwards]] and [[Ted Kennedy]], while if the player chooses Kerry, the player faces [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] opponents such as [[Donald Rumsfeld]] and [[Dick Cheney]].<ref name="GS" /> [[Hillary Clinton]] is the game's [[Referee (boxing)|referee]], and [[Ralph Nader]] is the [[ring girl]].<ref name="GS" /><ref name="IGN" />
The game contains a national polling system, which tracks online how many times each candidate is beaten by players. The game keeps track of both local and national results.<ref name="GS" />
==Reception== ''Bush vs. Kerry Boxing'' garnered positive reaction from critics who praised the game's humor and light-hearted approach to the election; it received a 75.5% from [[GameRankings]].<ref name="gr" /> [[GameSpot]]'s Steve Palley felt that the game struck up a good balance between humor and gameplay.<ref name="GS" /> [[IGN]]'s Levi Buchanan thought that the game was a "great goof".<ref name="IGN" />
==References== {{reflist}}

Bush]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Hillary Clinton]] [[Category:Video games based on real people]]

'''Michael Cadnum''' (born 1949) is an American poet and novelist. He has written more than thirty-six books for adults, teens and children. He is best known for his adult suspense fiction, and young adult fiction based on myths, legends, and historical figures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bookrags.com/biography/michael-cadnum-aya/|title=Michael Cadnum Biography|website=www.bookrags.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/michael-cadnum|title=Answers - The Most Trusted Place for Answering Life's Questions|website=Answers.com}}</ref>
==Biography== He was born in 1949. Cadnum attended both [[University of California at Berkeley]], and [[San Francisco State University]]. He earned a [[National Endowment of the Arts]] fellowship for his poetry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biography.jrank.org/pages/1911/Cadnum-Michael-1949.html|title=Michael Cadnum (1949–) Biography - Personal, Addresses, Career, Honors Awards, Writings, Work in Progress, Sidelights|website=biography.jrank.org}}</ref> He currently resides in [[Albany, California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/c/michael-cadnum/|title=Michael Cadnum|first=webmaster@fantasticfiction.com -|last=https://www.fantasticfiction.com|website=www.fantasticfiction.co.uk}}</ref>
==Bibliography== ===Novels=== * ''Seize the Storm'' (2012) * ''Flash'' (2010) * ''Peril on the Sea'' (2009) * ''The King's Arrow'' (2008) * ''Nightsong: The Legend of Orpheus and Eurydice'' (2006) * ''The Dragon Throne'' (2005) * ''Starfall: Phaeton and the Chariot of the Sun'' (2004) * ''Ship of Fire'' (2003) * ''Daughter of the Wind'' (2002) * ''The Leopard Sword'' (2002) * ''Forbidden Forest: the story of Little John and Robin Hood'' (2002) * '' Raven of the Waves'' (2001) * ''[[Redhanded]]'' (2000) * ''The Book of the Lion'' (2000) * ''Blood Gold'' (2004) * ''Rundown'' (1999) * ''Heat'' (1998) * ''In A Dark Wood'' (1998) * ''Edge'' (1997) * ''Zero At The Bone'' (1996) * ''The Judas Glass'' (1996) * ''Taking It'' (1995) * ''Skyscape'' (1994) * ''The Horses of the Night'' (1993) * ''Ghostwright'' (1993) * ''Breaking the Fall'' (1992) * ''Saint Peter's Wolf'' (1992) * ''Sleepwalker'' (1991) * ''Calling Home'' (1991) * ''Nightlight'' (1990)
===Short Fiction=== * ''Earthquake Murder'' (collection, 2018) * ''Can't Catch Me'' (collection, 2006, [[Tachyon Publications]]) * ''Together Again'' (2001) * ''Ella and the Canary Prince'' (1999)
===Poetry=== * ''Kingdom'' (forthcoming) * ''This Early Dark'' (2016) * "Day by Day" (2003) * ''Illicit'' (chapbook, 2001) * ''The Woman Who Discovered Math'' (chapbook, 2001) * ''The Cities We Will Never See'' (1993) * ''By Evening'' (1992) * ''Foreign Springs'' (chapbook, 1988) * ''Invisible Mirror'' (chapbook, 1987) * ''Long Afternoons'' (1986) * "Wrecking the Cactus" (pamphlet, 1985) * ''The Morning of the Massacre,'' (chapbook, 1981)

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2017}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:HMS Surinam struck by lightning.jpg|right|300px|HMS Surinam struck by lightning]] |Ship caption=HMS ''Surinam'' struck by lightning, 11 December 1806, by [[Nicholas Matthews Condy]], [[National Maritime Museum]], [[Greenwich]] }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=[[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] |Ship flag=[[File:Naval Ensign of the United Kingdom.svg|60px|Royal Navy Ensign]] |Ship name=HMS ''Surinam'' |Ship ordered=7 November 1803 |Ship builder=Ayles of [[Topsham, Devon|Topsham]] |Ship laid down=Feb 1804 |Ship launched=January 1805 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours=*[[Naval General Service Medal (1847)|Naval General Service Medal]] with clasps: *"Martinique"<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=20939|page=242|date=26 January 1849}}</ref> *"Guadaloupe"<ref>{{London Gazette|date=26 January 1849|issue=20393|page=243}}</ref> |Ship captured= |Ship fate= Sold for breaking on 20 July 1825 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption=<ref name=Winfield/> |Ship class= |Ship type=[[Cruizer class brig-sloop|''Cruizer''-class brig-sloop]] |Ship tonnage=384 ([[Builder's Old Measurement|bm]]) |Ship length=*{{convert|100|ft|0|in|m|1|abbr=on}} (gundeck) *{{convert|77|ft|4+1/2|in|m|1|abbr=on}} (keel) |Ship beam={{convert|30|ft|6+1/2|in|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship draught= |Ship hold depth={{convert|12|ft|9|in|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship sail plan=[[Brig|Brig rigged]] |Ship complement=121 |Ship armament=16 x 32-pounder [[carronade]]s + 2 x 6-pounder bow guns |Ship notes= }} |} {{other ships|HMS Surinam}}
'''HMS ''Surinam''''' was a [[Cruizer class brig-sloop|''Cruizer''-class brig-sloop]] built by Obadiah Ayles at [[Topsham, Devon|Topsham]], [[Exeter]] and launched in 1805.<ref name=Winfield>Winfield (2008), p.292.</ref> She captured one privateer during her twenty-year career and took part in two campaigns before she was broken up in 1825.
==Napoleonic Wars== In March 1805 Commander Alexander Shippard commissioned ''Surinam'' for the Channel and then the Mediterranean. In September ''Srinam'' captured the ''Merchant'' , master, which was sailing from New York, and sent her into Portsmouth.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no. 4254.[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1805/09-17-1805.jpg].</ref>
Shippard was promoted to [[post-captain]] on 22 January 1806. However, he was still aboard ''Surinam'' when she captured the ''Juliana'' on 28 February.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=16330|date=2 January 1810|pages=25–26}}</ref> A few days earlier ''Surinam'' had captured the ''Venus'', Robhen, master, which had been sailing from St Bartholomews, and sent her into Plymouth.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no. 4301.[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1806/02-28-1806.jpg]</ref>
''Surinam{{'}}''s next captain was briefly Commander H. Higman, and he was soon replaced by Commander John Lake in February 1806.<ref name=Winfield/>
On 11 May 1806. ''Surinam'' captured three vessels: ''Pacifico'', ''Tomasa'' and ''Alexandro''. Then six days later she captured the ''San Domingo''.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=15999|date=10 February 1807|page=179}}</ref> ''San Domingo'' was a schooner from Bilbao. ''Surinam'' also captured two luggers from Bilbao that may or may not be among the three vessels that she capture in May.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no. 4058.[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1806/06-03-1806.jpg]</ref> Next, ''Surinam'' captured the ''Anne Marie'', Claasson, master, from St Thomas, and the Spanish lugger ''Alexander'', and sent them into Plymouth.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no. 4061.[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1806/06-13-1806.jpg]</ref> Lastly, ''Surinam'' detained the Danish vessel ''Constantia'', Hankow, master, which had been sailing from St Croix to Copenhagen, and sent her into Plymouth too.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no. 4062.[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1806/06-17-1806.jpg]</ref>
On 28 July ''Surinam'' was present or in sight at the capture of the French frigate [[French frigate Rhin (1802)|''Rhin'']].<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=16056|date=15 August 1807|page=1075}}</ref>
On 11 December, while ''Surinam'' west of [[Belle Île]] watching for the French fleet under Admiral [[Jean-Baptiste Philibert Willaumez|Willaumez]], lightning struck her. The strike killed two men, wounded four, destroyed a mast and damaged her badly.<ref>Harris (1858), p.35.</ref>
In 1807 ''Surinam'' was attached to Admiral Lord [[Alan Gardner, 1st Baron Gardner|Gardner]]’s fleet off southern Ireland.
''Surinam'' left the fleet for Plymouth on 15 November. On 17 November, some 17 [[League (unit)|leagues]] north of [[Ushant]], she fell in with a French privateer. After a ten-hour chase ''Surinam'' captured the French vessel, which turned out to be the ''Amiral Dacrés'' (or ''Amiral Decrés''). The privateer was armed with fourteen 6-pounder guns and carried a crew of 76 men under the command of Jean G. Michel. She had sailed from [[St Malo]] the day before on her first cruise and had made no captures.<ref>{{London Gazette|page=1555 |issue=16089|date=21 November 1809}}</ref> At the time of the capture, [[HMS Pomone (1805)|''Pomone'']] was in sight.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=16313|date=7 November 1809|page=1787}}</ref>
On 22 October, ''Surinam'' captured the ''Jane and Eleanor''.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=16313|date=7 November 1809|page=1788}}</ref>
On 30 January 1808, ''Surinam'' captured the French sloop ''Sta. Anna'' or ''Sta. Joseph Marie''.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=16382|date=26 June 1810|pages=947–948}}</ref> A few days earlier, ''Surinam'' had detained the ''Grace, Brown, master'', which had been sailing from New York.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no.4224,[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1813/29-1-1808.jpg] - accessed 8 October 2014.</ref>
On 20 July ''Surinam'' was in company with {{HMS|Shannon|1806|2}} and {{HMS|Eclair|1801|2}} when ''Shannon'' captured ''Comet''.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=16507|date=23 July 1811|page=1411}}</ref>
Then on 21 August, ''Surinam'' was in company with ''Shannon'' and {{HMS|Martial|1805|2}} when ''Shannon'' captured ''Espoir''.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=16341|date=10 January 1810|page=223}}</ref>
On 9 November ''Surinam'' captured the sloop ''Jeune Henry''.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=16382|date=26 June 1810|page=946}}</ref> This may have been the ''John & Harry'', from Guadeloupe that ''Lloyd's List'' reported arriving at Plymouth on 15 November.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no.4302,[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1813/18-11-1808.jpg] - accessed 8 October 2014.</ref>
The next month, on 15 December, ''Surinam'' sailed for the Leeward Islands.<ref name=Winfield/> She arrived there on 26 January 1809 after having left delivered the vessels she was convoying to Berbice, Demerara, and Surinam.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no.4337,[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1813/21-3-1809.jpg] - accessed 8 October 2014.</ref> She had left the rest of the convoy, which was going to other destinations, on 5 January.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no.4329,[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1813/21-2-1809.jpg] - accessed 8 October 2014.</ref>
''Surinam'' was at the capture of [[Invasion of Martinique (1809)|Martinique]] in February 1809. In 1847 the Admiralty authorized the issuance of the Naval General Service Medal with clasp "Martinique" to all naval survivors of that campaign.
On 17 February 1810 ''Suriname'', {{HMS|Frolic|1806|2}}, and {{HMS|Superieure|1803|2}} joined Captain [[William Charles Fahie]] of {{HMS|Abercrombie|1807|2}} and his force at the surrender of [[Saint Martin]]. Fahie then entrusted ''Surinam'' with the despatches to Vice-Admiral The Honorable [[Alexander Cochrane]].<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=16356|date=31 March 1810|page=487}}</ref>
By virtue of this action, ''Surinam'' effectively also participated in the [[Invasion of Guadeloupe (1810)|capture of Guadeloupe]] in January and February 1810.{{refn|A first-class share of the prize money for Guadaloupe was worth £113 3s 1¼d; a sixth-class share, that of an ordinary seaman, was worth £1 9s 1¼d.<ref>{{London Gazette|date=24 September 1814|issue=16938|pages=1923–1924}}</ref>|group=Note}} In 1847 the [[Admiralty]] awarded the Naval General Service Medal with clasp "Guadaloupe" to all surviving participants of the campaign.
In 1810, Commander A. Hodge (or Hedge) took command,<ref name="NMM-WH-376871"/> and the next year she visited her namesake country of [[Suriname]], in South America. His replacement, in 1811, was A. Kennedy.<ref name="NMM-WH-376871">{{cite web|url=http://www.nmm.ac.uk/upload/pdf/Warship_Histories_Vessels_iv.pdf|title=NMM, vessel ID 376871|work=Warship Histories, vol iv|publisher=[[National Maritime Museum]]|accessdate=30 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110802041617/http://www.nmm.ac.uk/upload/pdf/Warship_Histories_Vessels_iv.pdf|archivedate=2 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 1812, Commander John Ellis Watt took command on the Leeward Islands station and sailed her for the coast of Guyana.
In August 1812 ''Surinam'' was in company with {{HMS|Swaggerer|1809|2}} when they captured four American vessels:<ref>{{London Gazette|page=1534|issue=16760|date=3 August 1813}}</ref> *''General Hamilton'' (11 August), lying at [[Paramaribo]], Suriname, carrying a cargo of molasses; *''Mary'' (11 August), lying at Paramaribo, Suriname, in ballast; *''Pochohantes'' (12 August), lying at Braams Point, Suriname, and carrying a cargo of salt; and *''Mercator'' (24 August), bound to Baltimore, laden with molasses. Watt died in September 1813 on his passage home after eight years in the West Indies.<ref>''The gentleman's magazine and historical chronicle'', Vol. 83, part 2, p.504.</ref>
On 6 September 1812, ''Surinam'' was near Surinam when she encountered the American privateer ''Montgomery'', which was under the command of Captain Upton. ''Montgomery'' was armed with two long 12-pounder guns and ten 6-pounders. ''Surinam'' gave chase until a shot from ''Montgomery'' struck and so weakened ''Surinam{{'}}''s foremast that she gave up the pursuit.<ref>Maclay (1900), p.379.</ref>
''Surinam'' encountered the American privateer ''Governor Tompkins'', of ten 9-pounder guns and 90 men, on 20 May 1813 off the coast of Surinam. After an engagement of some 45 minutes, ''Governor Tompkins'' was able to escape. Earlier, on 8 May, ''Governor Tompkins'' had captured the ''Hartley'', Grayson, master, which was sailing from Gibraltar to Bahia. The privateer burnt the ''Hartley'', and on 24 May deposited Captain Grayson and his crew at Grenada. ''Governor Tompkins'' then sailed for America, having been cruising for some three months.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no. 4787,[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1813/07-16-1813.jpg] - accessed 16 December 2013.</ref>
On 16 September ''Surinam'' and {{HMS|Grampus|1802|6}} arrived off Portsmouth with 37 vessels that they had escorted from the Leeward Islands.<ref>''Lloyd's List'', no.4805,[http://www.1812privateers.org/LLOYDS/1813/17-9-1813.jpg] - accessed 8 October 2014.</ref>
In 1814 ''Surinam'' returned to Britain. From October 1815 she was [[Reserve fleet|in ordinary]] at Sheerness.<ref name=Winfield/>
==Post-war== Between 1817 and 1820 ''Surinam'' was at Chatham.<ref name="NMM-WH-376871"/> On 18 November 1820 Commander William Mackenzie Godfrey took command and sailed for the West Indies. He was promoted to [[post-captain]] on 19 July 1822 and Commander Alfred Matthews replaced him. Commander Charles Crole succeeded him from April 1823. By 1825 ''Surinam'' was back at Chatham.<ref name=Winfield/>
==Fate== On 22 June 1825 the Navy Office offered her for sale.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=18149|date=25 June 1825|page=1109}}</ref> She was sold on 20 July 1825 at Chatham for £1,450 to John Small Sedger for breaking up.<ref name=Winfield/>
==Notes, citations, and references== '''Notes''' {{reflist|group=Note}} '''Citations''' {{reflist|30em}} '''References''' *Harris, Sir William Snow (1858) ''Shipwreck by lightning: Papers relative to Harris lightning conductors''. (Sleeper & Rogers). *Maclay, Edgar Stanton (1900) ''A history of American privateers''. (Sampson, Low, Marston & co,). *{{cite book |first=Rif|last=Winfield|title=British Warships in the Age of Sail 1793–1817: Design, Construction, Careers and Fates|publisher=Seaforth|year=2008|isbn=1-86176-246-1}}
{{Cruizer class brig-sloop}} {{WarshipHist}}

#Redirect [[HMAS Rushcutter]]

:''The following discussion is an archived debate of the proposed deletion of the article below. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.'' The result was '''deleted/userfied'''. [[WP:NAC|non admin closure]] '''[[User:TheWeakWilled|''TheWeakWilled'']] ([[User talk:TheWeakWilled|T]] * [[User:TheWeakWilled/Guestbook|G]])''' 20:53, 23 December 2009 (UTC) ===[[Final Solution (Book)]]=== :{{la|Final Solution (Book)}} – ([[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Final Solution (Book)|View AfD]][[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Log/2009 December 16#{{anchorencode:Final Solution (Book)}}|View log]]{{•}} [http://toolserver.org/~betacommand/cgi-bin/afdparser?afd=Wikipedia%3AArticles+for+deletion%2F{{urlencode:Final Solution (Book)}} AfD statistics]) :({{findsources|Final Solution (Book)}}) Refuted PROD. This book appears to be completely non-notable. Indeed, looking at the talk page, I'm not even sure if the book exists. Note that all the references are sourcing the history behind the content of the book, nothing to do with the book itself. [[User:Elen of the Roads|Elen of the Roads]] ([[User talk:Elen of the Roads|talk]]) 21:59, 16 December 2009 (UTC) :BTW, thanks Joe Chill for adding the template on the article. I didn't forget, but I use Twinkle and it does flub sometimes for no apparent reason--[[User:Elen of the Roads|Elen of the Roads]] ([[User talk:Elen of the Roads|talk]]) 23:43, 16 December 2009 (UTC) *'''Delete''': I found zero sources. [[User:Joe Chill|Joe Chill]] ([[User talk:Joe Chill|talk]]) 23:08, 16 December 2009 (UTC) *'''Delete''' self-published book. [http://www.matchstickentertainment.com/] No reason to think it notable -- not even in WorldCat. i recommend a SNOW. '''[[User:DGG| DGG]]''' ([[User talk:DGG| talk ]]) 23:18, 16 December 2009 (UTC) *'''Delete''' per nom [[User:DRosin|DRosin]] ([[User talk:DRosin|talk]]) 12:09, 17 December 2009 (UTC) As the author of this article I would like to request to move it back into my user space until I complete some of the tie in articles I wish to write. My series would include, The Final Solution (Jason Bailey), Final Solution (Lawrence Graham), and Final Solution (Richard Peck). The idea of these articles is to compare the difference between the coined term "Final Solution" historically to the fictional uses for it in literature. I understand that the article does not appear notable on its own but I believe when it is included in my series, this topic of comparison will be notable. I will wait until I get your permission before moving the article back to my user space. Thank you. 09:09, 17 December 2009 (UTC) —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Eraser1|Eraser1]] ([[User talk:Eraser1|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Eraser1|contribs]]) :Each article has to be notable in it's own right. This article will keep getting deleted until you show some evidence that the book has attracted the attention of the wider world. [[User:Elen of the Roads|Elen of the Roads]] ([[User talk:Elen of the Roads|talk]]) 17:35, 17 December 2009 (UTC) ::no reason not to attempt the general article you planned, but it should discuss only those books that are actually notable, and at this point your book is not among them. '''[[User:DGG| DGG]]''' ([[User talk:DGG| talk ]]) 18:01, 17 December 2009 (UTC) :::He's not planning to write a general article. He apparently wants to write an article like this one on each of the books he names.[[User:Elen of the Roads|Elen of the Roads]] ([[User talk:Elen of the Roads|talk]]) 17:18, 19 December 2009 (UTC) Eraser1 has moved this article into userspace.[[User:Elen of the Roads|Elen of the Roads]] ([[User talk:Elen of the Roads|talk]]) 17:00, 19 December 2009 (UTC) *''Delete'' for the record. What can be moved can be un-moved for no good reason. [[User:NBeale|NBeale]] ([[User talk:NBeale|talk]]) 14:17, 21 December 2009 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.

{{Documentation subpage}} ===Use=== This linkbox template creates a floating box linking to [[Wikipedia:Australian Wikipedians' notice board]].
The syntax for this template is: '''<nowiki>{{Australia NB}}</nowiki>''' {{Australia NB}} This template creates the linkbox shown at the right: {{clear}}
===Restriction=== This template may only be placed on pages with a prefix such as '''Category:''', '''Template:''', '''User:''', or '''Wikipedia:'''. This template should not be placed in the [[Wikipedia:Namespace|main article namespace]] <nowiki>{{NS:0}}</nowiki>.
===See also=== *This template invokes [[Template:NBbox]]. *This template is compatible with {{tlx|Portal|Australia}} and {{tlx|WPbox|Australia}} <includeonly> [[Category:Australia templates|Notice Board linkbox]] </includeonly>
